property_values.ai_title: The Dear Evan Hansen Movie: A Failed Musical Adaptation

summary: The speaker discusses the musical Dear Evan Hansen and its recent film adaptation. They analyze what went wrong with the movie and how it failed to translate the stage show to the screen. The speaker also touches on the trend of musical adaptations and the challenges of bringing Broadway shows to the big screen. The film adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen has several issues, including poor casting choices, particularly with Ben Platt playing Evan Hansen at an age that doesn't align with the character's high school age.

The film also struggles with translating the stage production to screen, making it hard to empathize with Evan's character. The music in the film is also criticized, with added songs feeling shoehorned and generic. The adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen for film has several issues, primarily with the cutting of certain songs and changes to the script. The speaker argues that these changes, such as cutting the song 'Does Anybody Have a Map?'

and replacing 'Good For You' with a two-minute argument scene, detract from the story and characters. The film's attempts to address criticisms of the stage show, like making Evan admit to lying on social media, fall flat. The speaker also criticizes the film's direction and cinematography, saying they don't effectively translate the stage show to screen. The speaker discusses the difficulties of adapting stage musicals to film, using Dear Evan Hansen and The Last Five Years as examples.

They highlight the differences between the two mediums, particularly in terms of how time and space are conveyed, and how musical numbers are staged and shot. The speaker argues that the film adaptations of these musicals often struggle to translate the unique qualities of the stage productions to the screen. The film adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen has been criticized for its awkward and uncomfortable musical numbers, poor directing, and drastic tonal shift from the stage show. The movie's attempts to ground the story in realism come across as forced and unnatural, leading to a dull and depressing viewing experience.

The speaker argues that the film's problems are not unique to Dear Evan Hansen, but rather a symptom of a larger issue with musical film adaptations. The speaker discusses their love for musicals, specifically highlighting Stephen Sondheim's works, and analyzes the current state of movie musicals, citing the box office failures of Cats, Dear Evan Hansen, and In the Heights. They express concern that film adaptations often lack the essence of what makes musicals great, such as strong choreography and emotionally explosive numbers. The speaker also promotes their content on Nebula and CuriosityStream.

And this again especially makes the romance section feel a lot more manipulative and a lot more calculated, and so we spend a lot of the show not empathizing with Ben Platt as intended and understanding how his own problems brought him this far and what it's done to him and others, but instead just being horrified that we're watching a serial killer origin story set to upbeat pop music.

And the thing is, this is partly an issue of the translation between stage and screen. Besides the fact that Evan Hansen's Broadway actors are already usually cast to be pretty young like it generally tends to be actors in their early 20s playing Evan Hansen, you also can get away with a lot more looseness in your casting when you're on stage based on the inherent fantasy of what a stage show is. is. Everyone understands when they go see a staged production that the things happening on stage are to some extent non-literal representations of the story. So this is a really minor example, but the Dear Evan Hansen stage has a screen where social media posts will pop up throughout the show.

This is obviously like a metaphorical representation of social media- the characters aren't literally having other people's Facebook posts blasted on a screen in front of them at their school. It's there for the benefit of the audience, convey what's happening in a non-literal way. Or even take a show like Hamilton, which, for all its faults, is still relevant to discuss when we're talking about what can and can't happen on stage. The way ensemble members manifest, sometimes as audience stand-ins, sometimes as historical onlookers, and sometimes as deeper representations of things inside the characters, like their guilt, isn't literal.

There isn't literally a group of people screaming no, no, no at Alexander Hamilton when he's about to cheat on his wife. Basically, when you enter a staged space, you implicitly recognize that elements of it are going to be larger than life and that these things will act as stand-ins for different things. Which is why, for example, an older actor can act as a representation of a younger character, and it doesn't necessarily matter very much. Half the ensemble members in Matilda are children, and half of them, the ones doing the more complicated choreography are adults, and it doesn't matter or look weird because we're pulled into the metaphorical space of Matilda.

Or even going outside age. The costumes in The Lion King aren't just fursuits designed to look like hyper-realistic lions, they're a mix of literal masks and puppeteering to convey the image of the animal they're representing, but also just clothing and costumes that get at the character's personality and feeling rather than an attempt to look like a literal lion. How a character looks in a Broadway show is often non-literal, and that's recognized and understood by audiences. So if Ben Platt is a bit older than he used to be in the role, it's not really that big of a deal because we're already suspending visual disbelief by stepping into the space.

The second reason is a lot more basic. Generally speaking, audience members at live shows aren't seeing actors in high definition. They'll be seated many feet away, even in the best best most expensive seats and sometimes an entire room away if you in the nosebleeds It just a lot less weird and noticeable for a somewhat older actor to stand on stage live than it is when you getting these close on their face in a movie theatre and every single wrinkle is on full display. Film is not only a typically much more literal representation of what we're seeing, which is why if they make a Matilda movie musical, adults playing elementary school students and hanging out with them on screen would look really fucking weird, but you also just get a much better look at people, seeing them up close, and in a much more grounded and realistic setting.

So when you're making a movie, whether it's with age or other physical traits about the musical characters, you need to be a lot more careful about the realism of whatever it is you're depicting. If you don't want whatever you're depicting in film to involve that kind of realism, it's going to take a lot more active effort because otherwise that's typically just the default of that medium. And when this falls apart for any reason, it's much more noticeable and problematic in film. Another really key element to making Broadway work on film is what you do with the music, And the film unfortunately fucks this up too. This is a tough position to tackle when you're adapting a musical for the screen. On top of being chock full of songs, another thing about Broadway musicals is that they tend to be very long. Generally speaking, music isn't thrust haphazardously into a show with no consideration for when a song should exist or why. Unless a musical is totally sung through like Les Mis or Hamilton, songs are placed at specific points in the story, with the most common adage about it being you sing when you can no longer speak.

These tend to be points of heightened emotion that are either personally important to the characters or just important to the broader story. My point is that cutting songs from musicals is often a necessary thing, but it's also a very risky one. And admittedly, that's because most people don't think about it in general. Cinematography, staging, and blocking are some of the great invisible magics of the art form. Things like acting and music and dialogue are all flashy and in your face.

They're things you can easily notice and observe and comment on regardless of your knowledge of the medium or any greater theory. It's pretty easy to tell how a certain casting choice affects the film, or if a song is performed well, or if a line of dialogue is good or bad. But generally speaking, things like blocking and cinematography are sort of meant to be invisible. Unless something is actively trying to be noticeable, chances are you aren't going to notice, the same way you might not notice exactly what you're doing with your hands in a certain moment, or where you are relative to the door in your room.

It's also the moment where a lot of movie musicals really, really mess up, especially recently. You see, as we've kind of talked about throughout the video, film and theatre are two different mediums and by extension have two different languages. Things that work on stage won't necessarily work on screen and vice versa. A lot of this is a difference in perceived realism.

In a stage production, you don't necessarily need to believe that the space people are occupying is a real space because, well, you'd know it's not. You're there observing a performance. You are watching people perform in a box in front of you. They exist in the same physical space that you do.

That means that a lot of the staging and production of stage shows are more… abstract, I guess is the best word. They can play around more with the environment, such as how Hamilton's set is a mostly static wooden room with a few props brought in every now and then. You can play with time, like having a character finish one scene and then transition into another scene without that character leaving the stage at all, or anything else that would give the theoretical idea of a scene ending. Think of how Come From Away has most of its cast on stage for the entirety of its show and just transitions effortlessly between moment to moment.

But I think one of the most important things unique to theatre is the way that a character interacts with the fourth wall. The fourth wall thing is quite interesting because it's a small matter that really does have a large effect on the overall perception of the work. For those who don't know, the fourth wall in a stage production refers to the fourth wall that would exist in a set. Considering how theatre has to be observable and cheated out toward an audience, rooms can't be closed and contained the same way they are in real life.

So a room in a stage show has a back wall, two side walls, and nothing else. What would be the fourth wall is the audience. And in a stage show, you can easily play with that. Because there is the unavoidable perception that this is all being performed to a crowd, you can simply have your actors, well, perform to the crowd.

I don't necessarily mean direct interactions, like calling out to them or mingling with them the way a musician might at a concert, though that certainly could happen, but it's more that because of the fact that you're aware you're being performed to, the actor, if they wanted to, could just stand there and, well, perform to you. No need for a lot of stage business, or sometimes even a background. You can just have the characters sing to the crowd amongst an empty backdrop and you're fine and it gets the job done and it works. But that doesn't work in a film.

Not really. The problem is that while the fourth wall in a stage show is the audience, the fourth wall in a film is the camera. And then later the audience will watch what the camera captured. And because of our underlying notion of cameras and how they work and what their purpose is, we generally expect them to record something matching close to reality.

I don't mean that that we expect everything that we see on film to actually be capable of happening in real life. Like, it's not like we're all watching Dune and going, this is bullshit. Worms aren't actually that big. However, there is this sort of idea that what we're seeing in frame is something that exists in the world of that frame, and that the world of that frame needs to seem like enough of a believable world to us.

It's generally why you don't see as much abstraction in film as you do in theatre, at least outside of art films. It's also why effects and props tend to get called out for not looking realistic more in film than they do in theatre. Unless it's like that weird bone saw inflatable that they used in Spider-Man Turn Off the Dark, what the fuck was that? The ways in which the language of the two mediums differ is honestly the root cause for a lot of the adaptational issues that you see in a lot of terrible musical movies.

If there's any style of theatre that takes full advantage of the abstract nature of the stage, it's musicals, and trying to figure out how to convert that into a film with different standards and understandings of how everything should be presented is… challenging. One of the ways this difference manifests itself, and a way in which it's especially noticeable in Dear Evan Hansen, is the way both stories convey the passage of time. The stage musical really wants to make it clear to the audience that Evan's lie, at least at the beginning, wasn't really something he deliberately set out to create. It was him not wanting to speak up in an awkward situation and correct a pair of grieving parents, and then it snowballed out of control from there.

And one of the things this show does do well is to convey the passage of time. Sets and characters often move around Evan who is the centerpiece, so once he's finished keeping up one aspect of his ruse, he's immediately onto the next thing. Evan is spending time with Zoe, and then immediately afterward, Alana is urging him to keep sharing his email exchanges with Connor. Or Evan is with his mom Heidi, and then the world moves around him, and immediately he's back visiting the Murphy family again, living in the temporary lie of a supportive, wealthy, nuclear family.

In a lot of ways, this conveys the exact same feeling Evan has- that he has no control over his life, that things happen to him. But in the film, that sense of momentum is no longer present. Characters and sets can't just move around Evan to keep up that feeling of constant pressure and snowballing. Instead, when we keep cutting to him going from his house to school to the Murphy home, it becomes a lot more grounded in our minds, and a lot more clear to us that like, this sense of constant action happening to Evan isn't really what we're seeing here.

There are long stretches of time between the things Evan does, and he keeps just choosing to go over and hang out at the Murphys when really, he could stop at any time. Along with the casting, and along with the musical changes, and along with the scripting changes, this is yet another reason we find it extremely difficult to relate to and sympathize with Evan, and another reason why he comes off as a fucking serial killer. The heightened, dramatic, very metaphorical tension around time and how Evan responds to it can't really work on film in the same way that it does on stage. Which means, when you're adapting it, if you want to convey that same feeling of things just snowballing out of control, you need to make certain changes to the way it's directed or what exactly happens in it in order to translate that feeling to a more grounded medium.

But by and large, Dear Evan Hansen just doesn't do that, and so we end up watching and judging Evan a lot more harshly than we would when we see him on stage. This is a challenge directors face a lot when they're trying to translate metaphorical or simplified versions of a staged story onto screen. You can't necessarily create the same non-literal visual shorthand as you can on stage, but at the same time, too much realism can actually weaken what a story is trying to do. I think the perfect example of this in action is The Last Five Years.

For those who don't know, The Last Five Years is a semi-autobiographical musical by Twitter name searcher Jason Robert Brown chronicling the relationship and eventual breakup of two people. Jamie, a self-absorbed asshole writer, and Kathy, a woman with anxiety and insecurity issues who needs more time and respect than what Jamie is willing to provide to her because he just didn't listen to anything and always put his needs before hers and… sorry, sorry, my co-writer Emily went through a breakup while writing this script, I don't know if you can tell. There are two things that make the last five years stand out. The first being that it's told from a non-linear perspective.

Jamie's side of the story is told in chronological order, starting with the two meeting and ending with him leaving her, while Kathy's side of the story is told in reverse, starting with Jamie leaving her and ending with the two meeting for the first time. The second thing that makes it stand out is, well, the fact that it's even split up into two sides to begin with. With the exception of one number toward the middle where the two stories sync up chronologically, Jamie and Kathy are never on stage at the same time. Essentially all the songs are solos, there is no ensemble, just one of the actors on stage singing about the relationship and then when they're done they tag out and the other actor comes in to do their song.

This is important to the way the last five years feels. For starters, it contributes to the feeling of disconnect between Jamie and Kathy. Considering how the musical starts with the revelation that these two won't actually end up together, having them have limited onstage interaction takes away a lot of feelings of intimacy the couple could have, and I mean that in the best of ways. It makes it especially clear, not just through the lyrics themselves but via the physical presentation of them, that there is an intense split and difference in how the two experience things.

And that's another reason it works so well. By dividing the two characters up, making it so that only one of them sings to the audience at a time, it reinforces the idea that what you're being presented is simply the perspective of the person singing at the time, rather than the actual objective truth of what was going on. Theoretically speaking, the point of the last five years is that by showing how each person saw the good and bad parts of that relationship, you understand both people's strengths and flaws, and also how they both contributed to the marriage not working. I say theoretically.

Jamie does a lot more blatantly terrible things throughout the show which are easier to point to and go, yeah, that's pretty fucked up. But for the most part, it does work out. Kathy will sing about frustrations with her career and feeling like Jamie is neglecting her and her interests, and then Jamie will come and sing about how hard it is to try and support her and be hit with a brick wall. Kathy will sing about how Jamie's success makes him too busy and makes her feel neglected, while Jamie will sing about how stressful trying to manage being a successful author is, and how terrible it can feel to have his wife seemingly judge him for trying to advance his career.

It's some honestly really interesting stuff, and despite some flaws and warts, The Last 5 Years is generally a good stage show, and I do recommend checking it out. But then in 2014, they decided to do a movie adaptation of it for… some reason. The film, starring Anna Kendrick and Jeremy Jordan showcases a lot of the issues that come up with translating a work like this to film And the thing that makes it so interesting is that there really isn anything garishly bad with the directing choices Yeah there a few things here and there that I can nitpick about such as the way they did Nobody Needs to Know, but overall, this isn't something like a Tom Hooper situation where it's just piles and piles of terrible decisions. Generally speaking, the directing is… fine.

The camera choices are a good fit for what they're going for. The switch between timelines and perspectives is made as clear as you could in film. The musical numbers are done with the energy that you'd want to have. There's no real egregious, oh, you decided to do this scene this way moment.

But yet the film just doesn't really work. And the reason why it doesn't work feels less because of any particularly bad choices and more just the differences in the medium. Because once again, we go back to that difference in the abstract versus literal. On stage, you can get away with only two actors splitting time on stage in a set that's just a single table and a bookshelf.

But that wouldn't really work in a film. If you tried that, it would feel too experimental, and too much like you just pointed a camera at a stage show. And the more complicated your set design gets, the weirder and more awkward it's going to feel to have a single actor belt a number in it without anybody else present, especially if the song is theoretically being sung to someone. So because of this, the movie basically disregards the only one actor on stage at a time setup.

Both of them are on screen together for a large part of the movie, there's a whole bunch of extras in each scene now, and in general, the film is shot and staged much like a conventional movie. This should theoretically make the show work better as a film, but no, not really. It's honestly a lot more awkward, the film didn't really make any real changes to the script or lyrics or any of the songs. Nothing substantial at least, they're all still written as, basically, solos meant to be performed more at air than at living people.

And because they're now being performed at other characters rather than at air, you get these honestly sort of uncomfortable scenes where a person will be singing to the other actor who has no choice but to just sit there and watch and try to come up with proper facial reactions. They did add some bonus dialogue to help balance it out and make it feel less one-sided, but it still sticks out really, really poorly. The end result is a film that didn't do anything egregiously wrong, but still feels like a significant downgrade over its stage version. Even if you don't mind the strange way the songs play out in the film, losing the uniqueness of the one-person-at-a-time staging does ruin a lot of of the show's impact.

It changes the way you see the two characters. It changes the way you see the two events unfold. In the play, what you're supposed to be seeing is a biased, one-sided perspective, and the staging reinforced that. But the film being shot more conventionally means that, theoretically, you're seeing an objective, reliable perspective.

It really breaks a lot of what the play is going for, and what makes it so unique in the first place, and it's not necessarily because of directorial choices, but rather just because the medium is so different that I can't imagine the last five years working on screen at all without it just being essentially a recording of the stage show. And honestly, what we can take away from the last five years' problems being adapted to film can be applied pretty easily to Dear Evan Hansen, because it also struggles with this. The difference being that the issues are less because of the format of the musical, and legit just the direction being overall pretty shit. Dear Evan Hansen is a lot more conventional of a stage show than the last five years.

It follows the standard beats you'd expect from a stage musical. Opening number, brief scene of dialogue, next musical number, that's an I Want song, scene of dialogue, musical number, dialogue, ensemble number, etc. There's nothing about the way Dear Evan Hansen is structured that makes it significantly different than your average Disney musical when you get down to it. So translating it to film wouldn't necessarily be easy, but it isn't impossible.

But oh god, talk about making essentially every wrong choice you possibly could. There's been this recent trend of musical movies that are seemingly ashamed to be musical movies, made by directors who don't really understand the genre or how to film it. Tom Hooper's Les Mis wasn't the first film to fall under this category, but it's certainly the most notable. Films in this category are generally made by prestige-slash-award-centric directors who will say that they're trying to approach the musical with a sort of grounded feel which just… no.

Like even the most downbeat of musicals is larger than life. The basis of the style itself involves people feeling so much emotion that they have to sing about it. Saying you want to make a grounded and realistic musical is like saying you want to make a subdued opera or a good video game music cover band. It's a fundamental misunderstanding of what material you're working with.

And yes, it is true that Dear Evan Hansen is more grounded than a lot of its stage contemporaries. This isn't a Hadestown or even a Hamilton. There's no elaborate dance sequences or complex musicality. Like I said before, it's basically your standard musical setup of dialogue followed by song followed by dialogue, and the world itself is meant to be as close to our modern day world and the songs are pretty much a standard pop affair with no real big showstoppers.

But like, even then, there still needs to be some attempt at making the music numbers via staging and blocking not be… bad. Theoretically speaking, the way you would shoot and block and film a musical scene is going to be significantly different than the way you'd just do a normal one. A musical number is a break from the reality of the world, leaving realism behind and prioritizing rhythm. So okay, let's take In the Heights, the movie, as a good recent example of this.

In the Heights isn't a perfect film. And I do have some issues with it, mainly the deviations from the original stage play and the complete gutting of Nina and Benny's storyline. But god did it feel good to watch a recent musical film that didn't absolutely hate being a musical In the Heights is admittedly a way more over show than Evan Hansen It a musical fans musical It made to have a large ensemble and have grand elaborate dance scenes and a million show-stopping numbers. So obviously the cinematography is going to reflect that in return.

Songs like 96,000 get this gorgeous pool sequence that feels straight out of classic cinema. Carnival Del Barrio gets long extended moments where the dancers simply get to play around and show off different dance styles from different countries. The opening number has a bunch of citizens in the ensemble out in the street. It can have these larger-than-life moments easier than Evan Hansen can, and it takes full advantage of that.

But that being said, there are still moments where Heights chills down and creates simpler sequences. No Me Diga is a festive and cheery number led by the closest thing the show has to comic reliefs, but something that stands out when you watch that part of the movie is just how deliberate everything on screen is. The simple act of walking across the salon and sitting on a chair manages to keep the energy of the song going with well-timed cuts that keep up the pace without being obnoxious and well-defined movements from the performers. There's not much here that's too elaborate when you get past the synced up movements of the ensembles and the mannequin heads in the back, but it still manages to feel interesting because the shots are interesting and the performers are making clear, defined, and engaging choices.

But okay, No Mediga is still a more high energy song than most of the ones in Evan Hansen. I wouldn't necessarily expect, nor would I want things like entire movable sets or weird mannequin heads anywhere in Evan Hansen. With that in mind, let's instead look at Breathe, one of the downbeat songs from In the Heights, and basically the play's first I Want song. Breathe is a slow and melancholy song about Nina, a young woman reflecting on her own anxieties and feelings of failure after struggling through her first year of college and coming back home.

To convey this on film, Nina is walking through the streets solemnly, seemingly aimlessly, observing those around her and reflecting on her own past life. Once again, we have a number without much that would be super demanding for our lead performer. The other people in the neighborhood do get more elaborate things to do, but even then the dances they do are slower, meant less for show, and more to replicate the type of dancing you might see from older couples dancing and remembering their own joy. It contrasts against Nina's feeling of aimlessness and her sadness.

The end result is that despite this number being so downbeat and depressing, you're able to understand how Nina feels directionless while still getting something that works as a scene and maintains an energy and structure to it that benefits the music. Now let's compare this to how they shot Dear Evan Hansen's I Want song, waving through a window, because good fucking lord, where to begin? So the song opens the movie and lets you graciously know right away that you're in for a nightmare because this number basically does every sort of film musical sing you could possibly do. You see, the first few minutes are honestly shot… fine.

Like, it's Evan singing to himself in a room. It's hard to fuck that up. But then the editing goes into overdrive. There's so many cuts here that are super frantic and fast, including one on every time Evan says tap.
I understand what they're doing here. They're trying to use editing to emulate what his anxiety feels like. But they did way too much. Like, you can't breathe.

It's like you don't even want to be around watching the movie anymore. I understand what they're going for, but it doesn't work, it's more funny than anything. We also get the next musical movie sin, which is overly literal interpretations of the lyrics. I get why this happens.

Once again, you have that problem where on stage you're allowed to have the actors just stand around and sing to the audience without worrying much about stage business, or props, or anything complex like that. And so it's easy to go through the lyrics and just match them up to what's going on. And in a lot of respects, it makes sense. Like, if Taylor Swift is singing about dancing in the kitchen around a refrigerator light, then yeah, you show her dancing in the kitchen around the refrigerator light.

But goddamn sometimes it can be really funny. One example of this was in the Les Mis movie in A Little Fall of Rain. The point of that number is that she's bleeding to death, She thinks it's raining because of the wet blood on her, but they just put a rain machine. Like the first time when Evan sings Waving Through a Window, he's actually looking through a window, and then when he sings Step Out of the Sun, he's actually stepping out of the car and into the sun.

And it's like, these are metaphors. You realize these are metaphors, right? There was never an actual window. It's like those TikTok videos of people doing literal interpretations of no children except this is done seriously and by a studio that spent millions of dollars on it.

You are coming down with me, hand in unlovable hands. Once Evan actually gets to the school, you run into the problem with how the extras are directed. Once again, much like the editing, I get what they're trying to do here. You see everyone else in school walking around Evan at their own pace, completely ignoring him and focusing solely on their own lives.

It's supposed to emphasize Evan's isolation and anxiety when it comes to being around others. But it's also done so fucking poorly because the extras are just wandering around with no real sense of rhythm, purpose, drive, anything. They don't need to be doing a dance number or anything, but right now it feels like they just gave them no direction but walk and then rolled the camera. It just completely zaps the energy out of what should be the climax of the song.

And it's not helped by the aforementioned weird cutting which takes things either too on beat or weirdly off beat or just does the weird moment where the camera does a 360 arc shot around Evan, but it keeps cutting and restarting where the previous cut started at. Once again, I do get that this is to emulate his anxiety. But it's doing so very poorly. When this is how you start your film out, I don't have any frame of reference as to what the film is going to look like when not in anxiety mode.

It just looks bad. Also, what the fuck is with this guy not actually hitting his drumset Backtracking a bit there a moment in this number where Evan Evan is in the car as his mom drives him to school This moment is small but incredibly incredibly awkward We have Evan singing his bit of the song while his mom is just there with him existing in the same space but failing to acknowledge what he's doing or participating in it. It just gives him a playful and comforting rub on the shoulder, which weirdly makes it worse than if she didn't acknowledge him at all- at least then it could be seen as Evan existing in his own world, divorced from everyone else. way that it's done makes it super uncomfortable. This is an issue basically all the musical numbers in the film have.

Once again, we're back in that last 5 years problem. The more grounded and realistic you make your film adaptation, the more additional players you add to a scene, the weirder it's going to be to try and force your characters to interact in it. Dear Evan Hansen doesn't have as many solos as the last 5 years does, but it still manages to look just as awkward as that movie does with basically all of its musical numbers. It certainly doesn't help that the first song we get after Waving Through a Window is For Forever, another Evan solo song which has him passionately lying as he fondly talks about his friendship with Connor to Connor's family.

Because this is a scene where only Evan sings, it's Ben Platt basically going off on a song where the people around him just have to stare and look and smile, with maybe Amy really needs a new Agent Adams interjecting with dialogue here and there. And this is a five minute song, so you have to live in this space, wanting to crawl under your chair from sheer discomfort for five whole minutes. The stage show is also like this. It's also Evan singing to a mostly silent table at the Murphy House.

The difference is that the stage show doesn't make me feel like I'm actually in someone's dining room watching a kid sing out of nowhere. The overall direction of the movie is way too grounded, way too serious, way too realistic that whenever a sparse song does happen, it feels like a surprise and actually ruins the flow of the movie and just feels very uncomfortable. Then there's just some weirdly baffling choices. Take the awkward semi-love song If I Could Tell Her, which is about Evan telling Zoe what he likes about her by pretending it was what Connor actually thought of her.

It's a very strange song since it is written like a love song and it is supposed to be the first song to start their romance plot, but it is also being presented to Zoe as if it's her brother's thoughts about her. I wouldn't know exactly how to stage this either, but I definitely wouldn't do it the way the movie does it. In the stage show, they do it in a relatively simple and basic way. Evan is in Zoe's room, which in this case is basically just a bed and a shelf, and the two get talking, and Evan gets closer and closer to Zoe until he's sitting on her bed, and it ends with him stealing a kiss.

It's simple, but it gets the job done. You see these two get more intimate as the song goes on, not just emotional but literally closer in space until the final moments, and with this you see a gradual increase in Evan's confidence. But then the movie decides to put this in the Murphy's kitchen, with the majority of the action being Evan and Zoe across from each other as they circle around the island kitchen. And like, this is a very wild disregard for cinematic conventions, because any time you've seen a guy and a girl circle around a kitchen island in film, it's in a scene where he wants to murder her and she's trying to figure out a way out.

It makes a song that was mildly creepy evolve into something intensely creepy. And it's not helped by it also cutting to these flashbacks that show the old pasty Ben Platt watching Zoey from afar across the years while singing about how much he loves her, which just really, really increases the stalker vibes. Both the distance and the flashbacks ruin the sense of intimacy these two are supposed to have, as they spend most of the song really far away from each other. It cuts to flashback, and then they're both sitting on the couch right next to each other.

The moments where the two sit beside one another lost and obscured through the edit. It just really, really isn't good. There's also just some minorly buckwild things. Like for some reason having Zoey and Requiem speed up a car and then come to a super abrupt stop, which was just not needed at all.

Super, super overkill for what's supposed to be an emotional song. That moment in You Will Be Found where they realized they need to explain why Evan's speech was filmed, so they have him mess up and kids laugh at him and take out their phones to record his embarrassment. Which is just… wild to me. Like, imagine if his speech did end up sucking and he wasn't able to turn it around.

What would they do with that upload? Post it to r slash cringe with the title, teenager drops his cue cards at suicide memorial for his best friend. Thankfully Evan didn't mess up his speech, so they instead uploaded it with the title, His Best Friend Died. You won't believe what he did next, which is the real title that they put in the actual movie for the really sad emotional scene, I shit you not.

Fucking choices. When this movie isn't making the worst choices possible, it's making the most boring ones. This film has a tendency to really, really go all in on shot-reverse shots, both in its musical numbers and also just in general. There are so many scenes that are just these long, static medium shots of the actors swapping back and forth with no other interesting camera choices or stage movements or anything.

This can be seen in scenes like the new song The Anonymous Ones, but can especially be felt in the way they shot Only Us. For context, this is the song where Zoe and Evan get together, with Zoe expressing her love for Evan and her desire to progress the relationship beyond bonding over her dead brother. It's the closest thing Dear Evan Hansen has to a romantic song, once you ignore or all the, you know, other stuff that might make it weird. And the movie decides to showcase these two growing closer by mainly showing them separated in their own frames, away from each other and across the room.

I'm not sure exactly why the film does this so often. If I had to guess, it could be because they just struggled to figure out exactly how to choreograph and frame a lot of these numbers and just defaulting to the most basic option. But another potential possibility is that it is this way because of covid restrictions, because yes, they did film this movie during the height of the pandemic, which means every shot you see on screen is a very good shot is putting someone's life at risk. So that's something, and would explain why they really try to keep everyone six feet apart and in their own frames.

There are some good moments that I will give credit for. Sincerely me, while still overall not great, especially toward the end with the random fucking go-karts and shit, manages to be the best number in the film by actually doing dancing, starting off with a fun single take shot and just generally feeling more structured and elaborate than the rest of the numbers. It really feels like they put a lot more focus here than they did with the others. There's also some bit of cinematography I like.

I know I ragged on For Forever, but I do think it's neat how the song basically ends by framing Evan on his own by the window, Connor's parents on their own, and then Zoe getting the frame to herself as they look at Evan. It shows the divide. How the parents are fully buying into Evan while Zoe is reluctant and distant from the others. But what makes me really like it is toward the end, during Words Fail, when we find ourselves back in the dining room with Evan once again toward the window, but this time with Zoe and her parents across from him sharing the frame, showing how united they are in this moment in their disgust toward this fucking kid.

It's like the one standout time of the cinematography actually doing a good job expressing how the characters feel through framing. As a whole, Dear Evan Hansen's directing is just… not good. It fails to understand how to best elevate the material, how to translate the work to stage, and how to make the most out of the musical numbers. I mean, beyond just looking at individual scenes, the film itself has an overall problem with its tone and direction that bring it down hard.

Part of the problem with doing the thing where you get these award-aspiring directors to make a film aimed primarily to garner critical acclaim and award recognition, and in my opinion Dear Evan Hansen is 100% an award bait movie, is that they're going to do what they can to emphasize the aspects of the project they feel will get it nominated for an award. As said before, this usually means trying their best to ground it to a sense of realism, one that's not necessarily gritty, but is raw. And not only does Dear Evan Hansen do this, but it also comes with the extra benefit of just sapping basically every ounce of comedy out of the scene and really playing up the emotions of everyone at all times. Basically every scene, every performance is shot and performed like they want you to cry.

That you're supposed to be moved by how profound it is. I was honestly shocked that they didn't just slap a for your consideration banner on the entire movie. The weird thing about this is that the stage show is a dark comedy. Like, it doesn't go all in on the dark comedy angle the same way similar works like, say, World's Greatest Dad do, but it was still funny when it needed to be. made sure to have a punchline, to have comedic beats, to have moments that broke up the tension.

I mean, the reason why Sincerely Me is basically the fan favourite number is because it goes all in on the dark comedy aspect in a way the rest of the songs don't. And despite the movie maintaining this song, it basically drops every other instance of humour. It's like the filmmakers saw the way certain parts of the fandom viewed Dear Evan Hansen as this sincere, heartfelt, tearjerker play about mental health, and decided to go all in on it. I mean, look at the way the marketing focused so heavily on You Will Be Found, the song that's supposed to be a double entendre about how Evan is going to inevitably be revealed as a liar, he'll be found, and used it completely sincerely as a song about mental health.

And every single interview and piece of promotional material is about the emotional impact of the story and how important and meaningful it all is, and it's so not the right way to go about this. I'm not just saying this because I think that movies should have more quips or something, I'm not Joss Whedon, I'm fine with a serious, introspective film that tries to do something emotional. And I can understand why, from their perspective, they might have thought that removing the comedy would show more respect for the subject matter and come off as less tasteless. but weirdly enough, it comes off as more so? Dear Evan Hansen is a show with a deeply intense subject matter and a very complicated main character. The presence of jokes and humor in the stage show act as a sort of acknowledgement of that fact. more a tangential plot device to a story which is fundamentally about Evan. Despite the story

300

301
00:25:17.526 --> 00:25:22.946

302
00:25:22.946 --> 00:25:29.006

303

305
00:25:39.806 --> 00:25:45.566

00:25:45.566 --> 00:25:51.326

307
00:25:51.326 --> 00:25:57.006

308
00:25:57.006 --> 00:26:01.726

00:26:01.726 --> 00:26:07.886

00:26:07.886 --> 00:26:13.006

311
00:26:13.006 --> 00:26:19.326
a suicide note against Evan's wishes, or she's a direct foil to Evan. A depressed girl who,

00:26:25.246 --> 00:26:30.766
possible and yet is equally alone and desperate for friendship and recognition. And depending

314
00:26:30.766 --> 00:26:35.626

00:26:35.626 --> 00:26:40.426
is largely because she simply doesn't get a lot of focus from the narrative. Unlike

00:26:40.426 --> 00:26:47.006
Evan or Zoe or Connor or even the other side teen Jared who gets bits in Sincerely Me, she

00:26:47.006 --> 00:26:52.466

318
00:26:52.466 --> 00:26:57.506
besides a couple of ambiguous throwaway lines, which leaves her character somewhere between

319
00:26:57.506 --> 00:27:03.586
either a minor villain or a character designed to parallel Evan's own mental health struggles.

320
00:27:03.586 --> 00:27:08.386
It's not that she necessarily needs to be a strictly good or bad person, but rather that

321
00:27:08.386 --> 00:27:13.746
Alana doesn't get enough depth or focus for either thing the writers were going for for her to really

00:27:13.746 --> 00:27:19.106
work. And so to see Alana, who is also in many castings the only character of color in the show,

00:27:19.106 --> 00:27:25.346
be kind of uniquely sidelined in this way, kinda sucks. All this to say that Dear Evan Hansen is

00:27:25.346 --> 00:27:30.546
really… an okay show. There are some really good parts in it, and I can see why someone would love

00:27:30.546 --> 00:27:34.786

00:27:34.786 --> 00:27:40.786

00:27:40.786 --> 00:27:45.746
mid-tier show. One that could make a pretty decent movie if it played on its strengths,

00:27:45.746 --> 00:27:51.586
but at the same time, also with a lot of room for things to work on and adapt and improve for a future

329
00:27:51.586 --> 00:27:56.866
version of itself. So a Dear Evan Hansen film could very much be an opportunity to address some of

330
00:27:56.866 --> 00:28:02.466
those aforementioned story weaknesses, bulk out the stuff that works or needs more focus, and cut

00:28:02.466 --> 00:28:10.066
out the stuff that doesn't. But then, it wasn't that. And it was, um, very bad, and widely mocked.

00:28:10.066 --> 00:28:14.786
And actually, it ended up doing the direct opposite of what it could have done. It cut out

00:28:14.786 --> 00:28:20.866

00:28:20.866 --> 00:28:25.545
So like I said a while back, this video isn't just about Dear Evan Hansen. I mean it is

00:28:39.466 --> 00:28:44.786

00:28:49.186 --> 00:28:55.026

00:28:55.026 --> 00:29:00.626

00:29:19.506 --> 00:29:24.626
Very much a what not to do situation. So for starters, let's talk about casting,

The way ensemble members manifest, sometimes as audience stand-ins, sometimes as historical

00:34:31.988 --> 00:34:38.308
isn't literal. There isn't literally a group of people screaming no, no, no at Alexander Hamilton

00:34:48.948 --> 00:34:55.188
will act as stand-ins for different things. Which is why, for example, an older actor can act as a

00:35:00.548 --> 00:35:05.508
Half the ensemble members in Matilda are children, and half of them, the ones doing the more

whether it's with age or other physical traits about the musical characters, you need to be a

the differences in that transformation are, and so necessarily we judge it in the context

00:25:59.806 --> 00:26:04.846

main_points: The Dear Evan Hansen film adaptation was poorly received, with many critics panning its translation from stage to screen. The speaker argues that the movie's failure lies in its inability to adapt the source material effectively.

The musical Dear Evan Hansen was a huge success on Broadway, winning six Tony Awards, including Best Musical. However, the speaker notes that the show has its weaknesses, including a lack of depth in its exploration of themes and forgettable music.

The speaker discusses the trend of musical adaptations and the challenges of bringing Broadway shows to the big screen. They cite examples of failed adaptations, such as Tom Hooper's Cats, and argue that studios consistently struggle to adapt musicals for the screen.
The film's casting, particularly Ben Platt as Evan Hansen, is problematic due to his age and appearance, which makes it difficult to see him as a high school student.
The film struggles to translate the stage production to screen, making it hard to empathize with Evan's character and understand his actions.
The music in the film, including added songs, feels generic and shoehorned, and doesn't fit well into the story.

The film adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen suffers from poor song choices, with certain songs being cut or replaced, which affects the story and character development. For example, the song 'Does Anybody Have a Map?' is cut, which centers Evan's mother as an important character and establishes a central theme of the musical.

The film's scripting changes, such as making Jared gay and altering the ending, don't effectively address criticisms of the stage show and instead make the story feel hollow and impersonal. The new song 'A Little Closer' is particularly criticized for being generic and not revealing anything about Connor's character.

The film's direction and cinematography are also lacking, failing to effectively translate the stage show to screen. The speaker argues that the film's use of blocking and staging doesn't work well, making the musical numbers feel unconvincing.

The fourth wall in stage productions allows for a unique interaction between the audience and the actors, which is difficult to replicate in film. This difference in medium can lead to challenges in adapting stage musicals to film.

The way time and space are conveyed in stage productions can be abstract and metaphorical, but film adaptations often require a more grounded and realistic approach. This can lead to a loss of the original's impact and meaning.

The staging and shooting of musical numbers in film adaptations can be awkward and literal, losing the energy and intention of the original stage production. This can result in a film that feels like a downgrade from the stage show.
The film's directing fails to understand how to elevate the material and translate it to the screen, leading to awkward and uncomfortable musical numbers.
The movie's drastic tonal shift from the stage show, removing comedic elements and focusing on emotional impact, comes across as forced and unnatural.
The speaker suggests that professional recordings of stage shows, like the Hamilton pro recording, may be a better alternative to film adaptations, offering a more authentic and engaging experience.

The speaker's passion for musicals, particularly Stephen Sondheim's works, and how they resonate with audiences. The speaker notes that Sondheim's death was a significant loss for the world of theatre.

The challenges faced by movie musicals, including box office failures and the risk of losing the essence of what makes musicals great. The speaker cites examples of successful movie musicals, such as Hamilton, and expresses hope for the future of the genre with upcoming films like West Side Story and Wicked.

The speaker's enthusiasm for exploring storytelling lessons in various media and promoting their content on Nebula and CuriosityStream. They highlight the benefits of these platforms, including access to exclusive content and a discount on CuriosityStream.

or just really about Evan and Connor. Dear Evan Hansen enjoyed quite a lot of success

and popularity for quite a while after its inception. But one of the things that did earn it backlash was this teen fandom that it had.

This has actually been a bit of an interesting shift in Broadway culture over the last five or six years Whether it the increasing accessibility of bootlegs that let people watch expensive musicals for free the growth of video sharing platforms like TikTok populated mostly by kids and teens or the late cult fandom that shows like Heather

got, there's been a huge boost recently in Broadway shows either specifically about teens

or marketed toward them, and this has become a pretty divisive thing in the Broadway community

primary setting and aren't really new, but those shows were never as huge as they are today and

Nowadays though, especially following the online success of a show like Heather's,

which ran off-Broadway and didn't make huge waves when it came out, but gained a massive following

00:12:54.324 --> 00:13:00.244
in two London revivals after an illegal recording of it got popular online, this trend has really

00:13:00.244 --> 00:13:05.764
exploded. Whether it's Dear Evan Hansen or Be More Chill or Mean Girls which I hate the music for

00:13:05.764 --> 00:13:10.484
so much and I am physically resisting the temptation to go off on a whole rant about, or The Lightning

Thief or The Prom, these… YA shows, I guess is the right word, have blown up in their numbers

00:13:16.964 --> 00:13:20.964
and popularity recently, and with them has come divisiveness.

00:13:20.964 --> 00:13:26.964
Shows that aren't fully about teens but are still largely popular with and marketed at least partly

00:13:32.644 --> 00:13:37.924
This divisiveness is broadly present when young people get into pretty much any new hobby ever,

00:13:37.924 --> 00:13:43.764

00:13:43.764 --> 00:13:49.844
politely at Broadway shows, or only being interested in teen musicals, or just like,

00:13:49.844 --> 00:13:54.964
existing in such large numbers that people feel that the genre is now pandering to them.

More Chill tend to broadly feature fairly samey music that's easy to sing and not super complex,

00:14:12.484 --> 00:14:18.484
relatively simplistic and straightforward lyrics, and, well, teen themes. Some of the frustration,

00:14:18.484 --> 00:14:23.044
then, with the recent popularity of teen musicals is this idea that there can only really be a

limited number of musicals that run on Broadway at any given time. And so many of the ones on right

00:14:28.964 --> 00:14:35.044
now and that seem to be getting made are just kind of okay and aren't super artistically interesting.

00:14:35.044 --> 00:14:40.484
At the same time, though, I dunno, more people getting into stuff and making it broadly accessible

00:14:40.484 --> 00:14:45.944

00:14:45.944 --> 00:14:51.724

00:14:51.724 --> 00:14:56.604
honestly, I think that anything that brings it to broader numbers is generally good.

00:14:56.604 --> 00:15:02.124
So as much as I hate Mean Girls, count me out of the whole backlash against teen Broadway

00:15:02.124 --> 00:15:04.404
fans who only like teen musicals thing.

00:15:04.404 --> 00:15:09.324
That being said, the teen fandom Dear Evan Hansen gained, its high school subject matter,

musicals like Great Comet earned it a fairly fast reputation for being overrated.

Despite the kind of grumblings from people who don't love Dear Evan Hansen about not

liking it or not getting what everyone sees in it, its success, both of the commercial

00:15:28.524 --> 00:15:33.804
and fandom variety, continued to skyrocket. And in 2020, it was announced that the musical

00:15:33.804 --> 00:15:38.404
would get a film adaptation directed by Steven Chbosky, the guy who wrote Perks of Being

a Wallflower and directed Wonder and worked on other musical movies like Rent or live-action

Another thing on Backlash to Dear Evan Hansen is that when the film adaptation got announced

00:16:06.064 --> 00:16:11.124
I did an informal poll of this on Twitter a while back, and a lot of people think this.

So when your assumption is that it's another Love, Simon, and then you click on the Wikipedia

00:16:20.564 --> 00:16:24.984
whose son just died and scams his way into being close with them and dating their daughter

00:16:24.984 --> 00:16:29.304
and also everyone fucking loves this show and it won a bunch of Tonys, you might be

00:16:31.564 --> 00:16:35.744
So there were a lot of hot takes on Dear Evan Hansen and how fucked up it is that this is

00:16:35.744 --> 00:16:39.904
a musical and like how nobody is talking about how fucked up this is and like this is so terrible

00:17:07.263 --> 00:17:12.464
So rumors were swirling about what the deal with this show is, and some of the cast was announced,

including Ben Platt reprising his role as Deer. The show was kind of in this weird spot. You had

a lot of hype for it from fans, especially just Ben Platt fans as he was still doing stuff like

The Politician, but also this sudden shock and backlash as people learned what the show was

00:17:27.644 --> 00:17:33.084

student, the more this film became a target of discourse and mockery. And with people surveying

the upcoming film in this light also came a sort of revisiting of the musical in this discourse.

00:17:50.124 --> 00:17:55.404
So you'd see think pieces and videos and tweets that sort of tried to reconcile with this question

00:17:55.404 --> 00:18:10.706
of like was Dear Evan Hansen actually ever good or was it always just kinda bad and overrated from the start And I think that actually an interesting thing to briefly address because a movie that bad because it adapted its source

Both in the sense of being a good piece of art, and also in the sense of what it had to say about

Especially good about the show is the relationship between Evan and his mom.

00:19:03.186 --> 00:19:08.786
It manages to be a really good throughline. The show starts with both Evan and Connor's moms

I think the show also does a good job of addressing the insincerity and performativeness that come

My speech?

Your speech is everywhere.

This morning, the Connor Project page, it only had 56 people following it.

How many does it have now?

00:21:20.226 --> 00:21:21.226
4,580.

00:21:21.226 --> 00:21:25.166
16,239!

00:21:25.166 --> 00:21:30.546
He is pushed to keep up the lie partly because a fundraiser in Connor's name starts, and

the less he posts and continually makes stuff up about his relationship with Connor, the

to in a pre-social media age really affected his lie. It talks about social media, sure,

But at the same time, it does kind of struggle with what it wants you to take away from Evan's

00:24:13.526 --> 00:24:14.526

do to a person, and they just don't. And finally, there's the fact that, for all

whatnot, all of the hashtag youwillbefound marketing, the actual death of Connor is really

00:25:06.046 --> 00:25:11.946

00:25:57.006 --> 00:26:01.726

00:26:01.726 --> 00:26:07.886

00:26:07.886 --> 00:26:13.006

00:26:25.246 --> 00:26:30.766
possible and yet is equally alone and desperate for friendship and recognition. And depending

00:26:30.766 --> 00:26:35.626

00:26:35.626 --> 00:26:40.426
is largely because she simply doesn't get a lot of focus from the narrative. Unlike

00:26:40.426 --> 00:26:47.006
Evan or Zoe or Connor or even the other side teen Jared who gets bits in Sincerely Me, she

00:26:47.006 --> 00:26:52.466

00:26:52.466 --> 00:26:57.506

00:26:57.506 --> 00:27:03.586
either a minor villain or a character designed to parallel Evan's own mental health struggles.

00:27:03.586 --> 00:27:08.386
It's not that she necessarily needs to be a strictly good or bad person, but rather that

00:27:08.386 --> 00:27:13.746
Alana doesn't get enough depth or focus for either thing the writers were going for for her to really

00:27:13.746 --> 00:27:19.106
work. And so to see Alana, who is also in many castings the only character of color in the show,

00:27:19.106 --> 00:27:25.346
be kind of uniquely sidelined in this way, kinda sucks. All this to say that Dear Evan Hansen is

00:27:25.346 --> 00:27:30.546
really… an okay show. There are some really good parts in it, and I can see why someone would love

00:27:30.546 --> 00:27:34.786
it, and there are also some pretty weak parts that make me understand why someone would either

00:27:34.786 --> 00:27:40.786
hate it or just not really feel much about it at all. It's, at least in my opinion, a safely

00:27:40.786 --> 00:27:45.746
mid-tier show. One that could make a pretty decent movie if it played on its strengths,

00:27:45.746 --> 00:27:51.586
but at the same time, also with a lot of room for things to work on and adapt and improve for a future

00:27:51.586 --> 00:27:56.866
version of itself. So a Dear Evan Hansen film could very much be an opportunity to address some of

00:27:56.866 --> 00:28:02.466
those aforementioned story weaknesses, bulk out the stuff that works or needs more focus, and cut

00:28:02.466 --> 00:28:10.066
out the stuff that doesn't. But then, it wasn't that. And it was, um, very bad, and widely mocked.

00:28:10.066 --> 00:28:14.786
And actually, it ended up doing the direct opposite of what it could have done. It cut out

00:28:14.786 --> 00:28:20.866
stuff that was desperately needed while adding things that some were bad and didn't work.

00:28:20.866 --> 00:28:25.545
So like I said a while back, this video isn't just about Dear Evan Hansen. I mean it is

00:28:25.545 --> 00:28:29.566
bad, and we are going to talk about that, but I want to look at it specifically from

00:28:29.566 --> 00:28:34.846
an adaptational standpoint. Why this movie didn't work as an adaptation of a Broadway

musical and what it can tell us about other adaptations and the task of doing that in

00:28:39.466 --> 00:28:44.786
general. Because taking a story that's designed to be told on stage, and especially one that's

339
00:28:44.786 --> 00:28:49.186
to be told with music and dancing and larger-than-life costumes designed to be visible

340
00:28:49.186 --> 00:28:55.026
from the back of a theatre and placing it into a much more contained and intimate medium-like film

341
00:28:55.026 --> 00:29:00.626
is always going to be a really big challenge. Which is why there's a massive litany of movie

342
00:29:00.626 --> 00:29:07.186
musicals out there that are safe to describe as like… pretty okay, but not as good as the original.

343
00:29:07.186 --> 00:29:13.266
But then, every once in a while, you get a Dear Evan Hansen. And there's just so much here that's

00:29:13.266 --> 00:29:18.946
just really telling in terms of the entire process of taking a musical and making it a movie.

345
00:29:19.506 --> 00:29:24.626
Very much a what not to do situation. So for starters, let's talk about casting,

346
00:29:24.626 --> 00:29:30.306
and specifically how Dear Evan Hansen was cast, and why it's absolutely buckwild.

00:29:37.106 --> 00:29:41.826
I will say one single positive thing about the casting in the Dear Evan Hansen film,

He originated the role as far back as the very very start when the show was in its initial readings He performed it at the Tonys and he considered the iconic face of Dear Evan Hansen He played a high schooler in Ryan Murphy The Politician

00:30:12.948 --> 00:30:19.588
like a year prior. His dad, Mark Platt, is a producer on the film. So yeah, it was gonna be

00:30:19.588 --> 00:30:25.908
Ben Platt who played Evan. And- okay, I know that it's not an especially hot or revelatory take at

00:30:25.908 --> 00:30:31.108

00:30:31.108 --> 00:30:36.708

twenties. Like, this is very standard for Hollywood at this point, but for the most part, they mostly

00:30:41.748 --> 00:30:46.628
look like high schoolers. Or at the very least, what we've convinced ourselves in our head from

00:30:46.628 --> 00:30:51.828

00:30:51.828 --> 00:30:57.668

00:31:13.268 --> 00:31:17.988
Also, side note, but the projector in the theatre my co-writer Emily saw this movie in was calibrated

00:31:17.988 --> 00:31:22.708
poorly and washed everything out and made Ben Platt's face look weirdly paler like polymer

00:31:22.708 --> 00:31:27.108
eraser white, which just made him look even more like a strange little freak.

366
00:31:27.108 --> 00:31:31.908
But the thing is, this isn't just a problem in the sense that it looks goofy and funny. It actually

00:31:31.908 --> 00:31:36.628
fucks with a really significant element of what makes this show mostly work on stage,

00:31:36.628 --> 00:31:42.708
and makes the entire story much harder to swallow. The original musical, for all its flaws and how

369
00:31:42.708 --> 00:31:48.388
exactly it depicts Evan and his actions, gives you a sort of understanding as to how an extremely

370
00:31:48.388 --> 00:31:53.268

00:31:57.188 --> 00:32:03.628

00:32:03.628 --> 00:32:10.048
not as a mustache-twirling manipulator, but as a kid who fucked up. When we see Evan on

00:32:10.048 --> 00:32:15.808

00:32:15.808 --> 00:32:21.948

00:32:21.948 --> 00:32:27.868

00:32:27.868 --> 00:32:34.748

deeply incongruous with what we are seeing on screen, and therefore become less understandable

00:32:52.988 --> 00:32:58.748
to us and more so deeply inappropriate. And this again especially makes the romance

00:33:13.228 --> 00:33:18.828
we're watching a serial killer origin story set to upbeat pop music. And the thing is,

386
00:33:18.828 --> 00:33:25.468
this is partly an issue of the translation between stage and screen. Besides the fact that Evan Hansen's

387
00:33:25.468 --> 00:33:30.828
Broadway actors are already usually cast to be pretty young like it generally tends to be actors

00:33:30.828 --> 00:33:36.188
in their early 20s playing Evan Hansen, you also can get away with a lot more looseness in your

389
00:33:36.188 --> 00:33:41.468

390
00:33:41.468 --> 00:33:46.388
is. Everyone understands when they go see a staged production that the things happening

391
00:33:46.388 --> 00:33:50.848

392
00:33:50.848 --> 00:33:55.388
So this is a really minor example, but the Dear Evan Hansen stage has a screen where social

393
00:33:55.388 --> 00:34:00.428

394
00:34:00.428 --> 00:34:05.188

convey what's happening in a non-literal way. Or even take a show like Hamilton, which, for all its

397
00:34:15.428 --> 00:34:20.388
faults, is still relevant to discuss when we're talking about what can and can't happen on stage.

398
00:34:20.388 --> 00:34:25.908
The way ensemble members manifest, sometimes as audience stand-ins, sometimes as historical

399
00:34:25.908 --> 00:34:31.988
onlookers, and sometimes as deeper representations of things inside the characters, like their guilt,

400
00:34:31.988 --> 00:34:38.308
isn't literal. There isn't literally a group of people screaming no, no, no at Alexander Hamilton

401
00:34:38.308 --> 00:34:43.748
when he's about to cheat on his wife. Basically, when you enter a staged space,

402
00:34:43.748 --> 00:34:48.948
you implicitly recognize that elements of it are going to be larger than life and that these things

403
00:34:48.948 --> 00:34:55.188
will act as stand-ins for different things. Which is why, for example, an older actor can act as a

404
00:34:55.188 --> 00:34:59.988
representation of a younger character, and it doesn't necessarily matter very much.

405
00:35:00.548 --> 00:35:05.508
Half the ensemble members in Matilda are children, and half of them, the ones doing the more

406
00:35:05.508 --> 00:35:11.028
complicated choreography are adults, and it doesn't matter or look weird because we're pulled into the

407
00:35:11.028 --> 00:35:16.468
metaphorical space of Matilda. Or even going outside age. The costumes in The Lion King aren't

408
00:35:16.468 --> 00:35:22.068
just fursuits designed to look like hyper-realistic lions, they're a mix of literal masks and

409
00:35:22.068 --> 00:35:26.708
puppeteering to convey the image of the animal they're representing, but also just clothing and

410
00:35:26.708 --> 00:35:31.268
costumes that get at the character's personality and feeling rather than an attempt to look like

411
00:35:31.268 --> 00:35:37.188
a literal lion. How a character looks in a Broadway show is often non-literal, and that's recognized

412
00:35:37.188 --> 00:35:42.788
and understood by audiences. So if Ben Platt is a bit older than he used to be in the role,

413
00:35:42.788 --> 00:35:48.628
it's not really that big of a deal because we're already suspending visual disbelief by stepping

414
00:35:48.628 --> 00:35:54.788
into the space. The second reason is a lot more basic. Generally speaking, audience members at

415
00:35:54.788 --> 00:36:01.108
live shows aren't seeing actors in high definition. They'll be seated many feet away, even in the best

416
00:36:01.108 --> 00:36:14.450
best most expensive seats and sometimes an entire room away if you in the nosebleeds It just a lot less weird and noticeable for a somewhat older actor to stand on stage live than it is when you getting these close on their face in a

417
00:36:14.450 --> 00:36:20.610
movie theatre and every single wrinkle is on full display. Film is not only a typically much more

418
00:36:20.610 --> 00:36:25.490
literal representation of what we're seeing, which is why if they make a Matilda movie musical,

00:36:25.490 --> 00:36:29.490
adults playing elementary school students and hanging out with them on screen would look

420
00:36:29.490 --> 00:36:35.490
really fucking weird, but you also just get a much better look at people, seeing them up close,

421
00:36:35.490 --> 00:36:39.490
and in a much more grounded and realistic setting. So when you're making a movie,

422
00:36:39.490 --> 00:36:44.130
whether it's with age or other physical traits about the musical characters, you need to be a

423
00:36:44.130 --> 00:36:49.170
lot more careful about the realism of whatever it is you're depicting. If you don't want whatever

424
00:36:49.170 --> 00:36:53.650
you're depicting in film to involve that kind of realism, it's going to take a lot more active

425
00:36:53.650 --> 00:36:58.450
effort because otherwise that's typically just the default of that medium. And when this falls

00:36:58.450 --> 00:37:03.410
apart for any reason, it's much more noticeable and problematic in film. Unless you're doing

something like Mamma Mia, which just doesn't give a shit and doesn't pretend to give a shit,

if your actors look slightly off for the part, it's incredibly obvious. Meryl Streep is obviously

an amazing actor, but the way she was cast and styled in something like Into the Woods,

which is my favourite musical and I feel very strongly about this, just doesn't work in the

the more toned down, grounded approach it has on film compared to stage. Look at Bernadette

lady, and you can see how big and dramatic that shift later is when she's transformed

film just in general because of the cartoonishness of it, but they try to resolve this in the

film with a much more realistic witch, and that makes the big transformation look like

very… nothing. Like, she just has neater hair and slightly fewer wrinkles and bags

under her eyes. She didn't need to send everyone in her little magic village on a

fetch quest for beauty, she could just brush her hair and put a bit of foundation on and

she would look the exact same. And the fact that we are looking at her up close throughout

the differences in that transformation are, and so necessarily we judge it in the context

In terms of casting for the rest of Dear Evan Hansen, it's for the most part fine.

Another really key element to making Broadway work on film is what you do with the music,

we go back to that difference in the abstract versus literal. On stage, you can get away with

00:46:26.852 --> 00:46:27.852
wild to me.

00:46:27.852 --> 00:46:32.612
Like, imagine if his speech did end up sucking and he wasn't able to turn it around. What

would they do with that upload? Post it to r slash cringe with the title, teenager drops

his cue cards at suicide memorial for his best friend. Thankfully Evan didn't mess

up his speech, so they instead uploaded it with the title, His Best Friend Died. You won't believe

00:46:48.572 --> 00:46:53.212
what he did next, which is the real title that they put in the actual movie for the really sad

00:46:53.212 --> 00:46:58.492
emotional scene, I shit you not. Fucking choices. When this movie isn't making the worst choices

possible, it's making the most boring ones. This film has a tendency to really, really go all in on

shot-reverse shots, both in its musical numbers and also just in general. There are so many scenes

dead brother. It's the closest thing Dear Evan Hansen has to a romantic song, once you ignore

or all the, you know, other stuff that might make it weird.

00:47:42.052 --> 00:47:47.092

in their own frames, away from each other and across the room.

I'm not sure exactly why the film does this so often.

00:47:54.192 --> 00:47:57.912
If I had to guess, it could be because they just struggled to figure out exactly how to

00:47:57.912 --> 00:48:02.832
choreograph and frame a lot of these numbers and just defaulting to the most basic option.

00:24:05.966 --> 00:24:11.726
is putting someone's life at risk. So that's something, and would explain why they really

try to keep everyone six feet apart and in their own frames.

1149
00:24:15.086 --> 00:24:19.726
There are some good moments that I will give credit for. Sincerely me, while still overall

00:24:19.726 --> 00:24:23.966
not great, especially toward the end with the random fucking go-karts and shit, manages to be

shot and just generally feeling more structured and elaborate than the rest of the numbers.

00:24:51.406 --> 00:24:56.766

00:24:56.766 --> 00:25:01.566

00:25:10.126 --> 00:25:14.846

00:25:14.846 --> 00:25:19.726
It's like the one standout time of the cinematography actually doing a good job

1164
00:25:22.606 --> 00:25:28.606
As a whole, Dear Evan Hansen's directing is just… not good. It fails to understand how to best

00:25:28.606 --> 00:25:32.686
elevate the material, how to translate the work to stage, and how to make the most out of the

1166
00:25:32.686 --> 00:25:37.726

00:25:37.726 --> 00:25:42.606
problem with its tone and direction that bring it down hard. Part of the problem with doing the

00:25:47.646 --> 00:25:53.086

will get it nominated for an award. As said before, this usually means trying their best

00:26:06.206 --> 00:26:10.766
And not only does Dear Evan Hansen do this, but it also comes with the extra benefit of just

sapping basically every ounce of comedy out of the scene and really playing up the emotions of

everyone at all times. Basically every scene, every performance is shot and performed like they want

00:26:22.126 --> 00:26:25.726
you to cry. That you're supposed to be moved by how profound it is.

1177
00:26:52.126 --> 00:27:05.466
I was honestly shocked that they didn't just slap a for your consideration banner on the

00:27:05.466 --> 00:27:06.586
entire movie.

1179
00:27:06.586 --> 00:27:10.466
The weird thing about this is that the stage show is a dark comedy.

00:27:10.466 --> 00:27:15.366
Like, it doesn't go all in on the dark comedy angle the same way similar works like, say,

1181
00:27:15.366 --> 00:27:18.706
World's Greatest Dad do, but it was still funny when it needed to be.

1182
00:27:18.706 --> 00:27:23.586
made sure to have a punchline, to have comedic beats, to have moments that broke up the tension.

1183
00:27:23.586 --> 00:27:29.066
I mean, the reason why Sincerely Me is basically the fan favourite number is because it goes

1184
00:27:29.066 --> 00:27:33.766
all in on the dark comedy aspect in a way the rest of the songs don't. And despite

1185
00:27:33.766 --> 00:27:38.226
the movie maintaining this song, it basically drops every other instance of humour.

00:27:38.226 --> 00:27:42.946
It's like the filmmakers saw the way certain parts of the fandom viewed Dear Evan Hansen

1187
00:27:42.946 --> 00:27:47.866
as this sincere, heartfelt, tearjerker play about mental health, and decided to go all

00:27:47.866 --> 00:27:52.906
in on it. I mean, look at the way the marketing focused so heavily on You Will Be Found, the

song that's supposed to be a double entendre about how Evan is going to inevitably be revealed

as a liar, he'll be found, and used it completely sincerely as a song about mental health. And

1191
00:28:03.346 --> 00:28:07.906
every single interview and piece of promotional material is about the emotional impact of the

1192
00:28:07.906 --> 00:28:13.906
story and how important and meaningful it all is, and it's so not the right way to go about this.

1193
00:28:13.906 --> 00:28:18.146
I'm not just saying this because I think that movies should have more quips or something,

I'm not Joss Whedon, I'm fine with a serious, introspective film that tries to do something

00:28:23.346 --> 00:28:27.506
emotional. And I can understand why, from their perspective, they might have thought that removing

the comedy would show more respect for the subject matter and come off as less tasteless.

00:28:32.546 --> 00:28:38.546
but weirdly enough, it comes off as more so? When you have those darkly comedic elements,

you're allowed to get away with things you probably wouldn't have otherwise.

1199
00:28:42.226 --> 00:28:47.186
Dear Evan Hansen is a show with a deeply intense subject matter and a very complicated main

00:28:47.186 --> 00:28:52.146
character. The presence of jokes and humor in the stage show act as a sort of acknowledgement

1201
00:28:52.146 --> 00:28:57.666
of that fact. It's the show giving a wink toward the audience, letting us know that it understands

the absurdity and potential tastelessness of what the characters are doing.

00:29:02.246 --> 00:29:07.586
And more importantly, it makes Evan more charming and relatable and human. By showing him engaging

in conversations with others, allowing himself to be funny and tell jokes and have moments

00:29:12.226 --> 00:29:16.526
that are played for soft laughs, we can gain more sympathy for him throughout the show

00:29:16.526 --> 00:29:21.626
and see him more as a flawed human being. In the movie though, where everything is played

00:29:21.626 --> 00:29:27.546
so dry and seriously, you have no choice but to examine the implications of everything going

00:29:27.546 --> 00:29:32.826
on. Without Evan's awkward banter with Zoe played for laughs, the film forces you to

think about how creepy their relationship actually is. With the school's sad reaction

to Connor's death played almost completely seriously, you have no choice but to think

1211

about how little the play is actually about him and how fucked up it is to use a teenager's

suicide purely as a plot device without actually fundamentally exploring the implication.

1213
00:29:54.046 --> 00:29:58.206
And without the charm Ben Platt could give Evan on stage, your mind is eventually going

00:29:58.206 --> 00:30:15.846
to drift off into examining how the film actually does explore his mental health issues and mental health in general and whether or not it actually covers the subject well I think this is a big reason why critical reaction to the movie has been significantly worse than that of the musical Beyond Ben Platt age beyond the musical

00:30:15.846 --> 00:30:21.445
numbers not being very good or well-directed, the drastic tonal shift honestly makes the material

00:30:21.445 --> 00:30:27.206
so much worse. By trying to make the work deeper, they essentially forced critics to dig into it
