more, which meant the work being basically exposed and torn apart in ways it really hadn't before.

1218
00:30:32.486 --> 00:30:37.846
Or at least that's how it felt to me, because god the movie feels so much worse. So so much worse.

1219
00:30:38.406 --> 00:30:43.445
Musical movies are very hard to do. Sometimes they can elevate the original work,

1220
00:30:43.445 --> 00:30:47.445
like how Chicago managed to become more interesting than its stage counterpart by

changing the musical numbers into these explicit dream sequences representing what's going on in

the real world. And as fun as ways to get a musical number to make sense on film go,

Saying it takes place on a fictional stage in a cabaret representing someone's psyche

is as good of a method as any. God, I love how they do the scene where that one lady gets hanged.

00:31:06.726 --> 00:31:11.046
It's so fucking good. And sometimes musical films can be done just as well as their stage

counterparts. Films like Little Shop of Horrors, Cabaret, Rocky Horror Picture Show, and even

Hairspray manage to translate what worked on the theatrical show to screen and are overall enjoyable

00:31:21.686 --> 00:31:27.125
experiences in their own right. And sometimes you have Cats, which exists in a tier all on its own,

00:31:27.125 --> 00:31:31.926
away from any sort of judgement beyond our moral comprehension. And then you have the bad ones,

1230
00:31:31.926 --> 00:31:36.486
the ones that really miss the mark. You're Les Mis, you're Phantom, you're Into the Woods,

1231
00:31:36.486 --> 00:31:41.445
which aren't just bad films, but actively seem to misunderstand and work against the appeal of

1232
00:31:41.445 --> 00:31:47.046
the original version. Dear Evan Hansen falls into that category, as do a lot of musical films,

1233
00:31:47.046 --> 00:31:52.165
unfortunately. And the thing that sucks is that for a lot of shows, film adaptations like these

00:31:52.165 --> 00:31:57.206
are the only way that most people can experience them. Meaning that a lot of the times, if you want

to experience a show you like in ways other than just listening to the cast recording,

you're left with little option but to watch a subpar screen adaptation. But what if there were

other options. So for the longest time, it seemed like there was a clear path for the life of a

musical. It runs on stage, and then if the producers decide that it's run for enough time

of the Opera almost 20 years after it debuted on Broadway. And if the Phantom movie sucks, well,

Sorry. Guess we'll just have to go grab tickets to a live performance.

00:32:40.566 --> 00:32:45.765
However, this has changed a bit recently. I did a whole other video on this. But this increased

demand for musicals and the nature of the internet has created an entire platform for

This dramatically changes the way in which we look at these film adaptations.

Before the internet, musical bootlegs weren't necessarily impossible, but they were a lot

harder to just stumble across. But now, if you want to find a bootleg of a show, you can just

google that show and chances are you can find it pretty easily. Not that I would condone such a

thing, but I'm just saying that trying to say you need a film adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen to

1251
00:33:18.486 --> 00:33:24.166
immortalize Ben Platt's performance rings a bit hollow in a world where I can google blue slime

00:33:24.166 --> 00:33:30.086
tutorial and find a video of the original Broadway cast. Bootlegs especially rose to greater prominence

1253
00:33:30.086 --> 00:33:35.166
in 2020, as with the global worldwide panini shutting down theatres, they became the only

00:33:35.166 --> 00:33:38.425
way for people to consume shows during that time.

00:33:38.425 --> 00:33:42.326
And I don't have anything to prove this, but I personally think that this also affected

00:33:42.326 --> 00:33:44.906
the way theatre companies viewed bootlegs.

00:33:44.906 --> 00:33:49.746
Beforehand, years ago, bootlegs and slime tutorials would get taken down super quickly

00:33:49.746 --> 00:33:51.746
and super easily.

00:33:51.746 --> 00:33:56.045
Someone would upload that one DVD-fab bootleg of Hamilton, if you know the one, you know

the one, and you only had a few hours to watch it before it was taken down. Same with Hadestown

and Dear Evan Hansen and other big productions. But now there's just a plethora of bootlegs on

YouTube, with hundreds of thousands of views that have been up for months, if not years.

00:34:12.446 --> 00:34:17.726
It definitely seems like the powers that be have gotten so much more relaxed about this sort of

thing, which is nice because it opens a lot more opportunities for people to experience a lot more

shows. Bootlegs aren't perfect. They generally have poor visual quality, sometimes the camera

won't focus on the things you want focused on, and sometimes you just can't see or hear what's

the camcorder bootleg of Dear Evan Hansen over the $30 million film adaptation. But if the visuals,

00:34:51.246 --> 00:34:57.086
or questionable legality of bootlegs bothers you, that's fine and understandable. Watching a stage

00:34:57.086 --> 00:35:01.805
version of a show can be nice, but you might not like tracking down a version on an illicit source

00:35:01.805 --> 00:35:07.006
that's filmed on someone's potato. Well, that's where you get to one of the other, more interesting

00:35:07.006 --> 00:35:12.446
recent developments- pro recordings. Professional recordings of stage shows aren't anything new-

they've technically been around for a while. But they were generally pretty rare. Much like film

adaptations, a lot of theatre companies don't want to have an outside version of the show that could

potentially disincentivise someone from actually seeing it live. As such, pro recordings were

generally only released for shows that had been going on for a while or that weren't going to be

1279

and Phantom of the Opera to finally get professional recordings. Although, pretty much every show has

00:35:42.766 --> 00:35:47.586
has a proper camera recording of it, New York Public Library has access to it, it's just

00:35:47.586 --> 00:35:52.366
that most of us are not allowed to go in there and watch those things. Fun fact.

1282
00:35:52.366 --> 00:35:56.526
That being said, pro recordings have their own unique problem. Part of the reason why

1283
00:35:56.526 --> 00:36:01.366
you still saw film adaptations more than pro recordings is because for a while, there wasn't

1284
00:36:01.366 --> 00:36:19.605
really a good way to distribute pro recordings at least not in a way that would maximize profits Recordings of live shows and concerts don usually get theatrical runs which meant for a while the only method for releasing pro recordings was direct and direct Which is fine But well direct video

1285
00:36:19.605 --> 00:36:24.406
stuff used to come with this stigma of being of lesser quality than theatrical counterparts.

1286
00:36:24.406 --> 00:36:28.726
And it would almost certainly mean not making as much money. There was some hope that this could

1287

change though. Back in 2016, renowned lip-biter Lin-Manuel Miranda made sure to get a full HD

professional recording of Hamilton done with the original Broadway cast. The goal was to keep the

recording in storage for a little while before debuting it to the public. And sure enough,

00:36:43.766 --> 00:36:48.886
the mouse himself Disney bought the rights to it for $75 million with plans to give it a full

theatrical release on October 15th, 2021. And then, like, the world shut down. And so instead,

it was retooled into a Disney Plus exclusive, and its release pushed way, way up to July 3rd,

00:37:00.165 --> 00:37:06.485
2020. And it was a huge, huge success. Now, there's a lot of discourse about Hamilton,

1294
00:37:06.485 --> 00:37:10.805
discourse that is banned from this channel because I do not want to get into it, but I'll say this,

1295
00:37:10.805 --> 00:37:16.566
the Hamilton Pro recording does a very, very good job replicating the energy of the stage show.

1296
00:37:16.566 --> 00:37:20.966
Whatever you like about the stage show is basically still here, and if you like Hamilton,

1297
00:37:20.966 --> 00:37:25.846
you'll like the pro recording, and if you've never experienced Hamilton, then you'll get a quality

1298
00:37:25.846 --> 00:37:30.886
initial experience with this. And most importantly, this thing was fucking massive.

1299
00:37:30.886 --> 00:37:34.886
Streaming companies don't generally release viewer numbers, but going by estimates,

00:37:34.886 --> 00:37:40.805
Hamilton was viewed by around 22 million people in its first month of release, which is a stupidly

1301
00:37:40.805 --> 00:37:45.526
high number. It was the second most watched straight to streaming title that year, right

00:37:45.526 --> 00:37:51.925
behind Wonder Woman 1984. This is really interesting because it showed that, under the right circumstances,

00:37:51.925 --> 00:37:57.226
audiences are 100% willing to watch a recorded version of a stage show rather than a full

1305

to distribute these sort of things. Much like the way it's easy to stumble across and

00:38:11.665 --> 00:38:16.545
they're curious about on a subscription streaming platform and watch them. And the demand for such

1308
00:38:16.545 --> 00:38:21.906
things is there and huge. It's difficult to say how Hamilton's streaming version success will

affect other productions going forward. Not all shows were lucky enough to have filmed a performance

years before the lockdown, so there weren't a lot of immediate copycats trying to imitate its success.

We have seen one, though. Before the pandemic, there were plans to adapt Come From Away into a

feature film, which is just… not a great idea if you've seen that show. Like, a large part of its

appeal is experimenting with the theatre format and its ensemble and the pacing and intensity of

Evan or Zoe or Connor or even the other side teen Jared who gets bits in Sincerely Me, she

interacts with the fourth wall. The fourth wall thing is quite interesting because it's a small
matter that really does have a large effect on the overall perception of the work. For those who
don't know, the fourth wall in a stage production refers to the fourth wall that would exist in a set.
Considering how theatre has to be observable and cheated out toward an audience,
rooms can't be closed and contained the same way they are in real life. So a room in a stage show
has a back wall, two side walls, and nothing else. What would be the fourth wall is the audience.
And in a stage show, you can easily play with that. Because there is the unavoidable perception
that this is all being performed to a crowd, you can simply have your actors, well, perform to the
crowd. I don't necessarily mean direct interactions, like calling out to them or mingling with them the
way a musician might at a concert, though that certainly could happen, but it's more that because
of the fact that you're aware you're being performed to, the actor, if they wanted to,
could just stand there and, well, perform to you. No need for a lot of stage business,
or sometimes even a background. You can just have the characters sing to the crowd amongst an empty
backdrop and you're fine and it gets the job done and it works. But that doesn't work in a film.
Not really. The problem is that while the fourth wall in a stage show is the audience, the fourth
wall in a film is the camera. And then later the audience will watch what the camera captured.
And because of our underlying notion of cameras and how they work and what their purpose is,
we generally expect them to record something matching close to reality. I don't mean that
that we expect everything that we see on film to actually be capable of happening in real
life. Like, it's not like we're all watching Dune and going, this is bullshit. Worms aren't
actually that big.
However, there is this sort of idea that what we're seeing in frame is something that exists
in the world of that frame, and that the world of that frame needs to seem like enough of
a believable world to us. It's generally why you don't see as much abstraction in
film as you do in theatre, at least outside of art films. It's also why effects and
props tend to get called out for not looking realistic more in film than they do in theatre.

movies. If there's any style of theatre that takes full advantage of the abstract nature of the stage,
it's musicals, and trying to figure out how to convert that into a film with different standards
and understandings of how everything should be presented.

00:19:42.146 --> 00:19:47.986
Things like acting and music and dialogue are all flashy and in your face. They're things you can

00:19:47.986 --> 00:19:53.106

00:19:53.106 --> 00:19:58.546

00:20:04.386 --> 00:20:09.506

00:20:51.026 --> 00:20:55.746

00:20:57.306 --> 00:21:01.946
That means that a lot of the staging and production of stage shows are more… abstract, I guess

00:21:34.046 --> 00:21:38.846

00:21:38.846 --> 00:21:43.646
matter that really does have a large effect on the overall perception of the work. For those who

247
00:21:43.646 --> 00:21:49.406

00:21:49.406 --> 00:21:53.726
Considering how theatre has to be observable and cheated out toward an audience,

00:21:53.726 --> 00:21:59.246

00:22:04.926 --> 00:22:09.726

that this is all being performed to a crowd, you can simply have your actors, well, perform to the

00:22:15.086 --> 00:22:20.286
crowd. I don't necessarily mean direct interactions, like calling out to them or mingling with them the

way a musician might at a concert, though that certainly could happen, but it's more that because

255
00:22:25.086 --> 00:22:29.166
of the fact that you're aware you're being performed to, the actor, if they wanted to,

256
00:22:29.166 --> 00:22:34.446
could just stand there and, well, perform to you. No need for a lot of stage business,

257
00:22:34.446 --> 00:22:39.326
or sometimes even a background. You can just have the characters sing to the crowd amongst an empty

258
00:22:39.326 --> 00:22:45.246
backdrop and you're fine and it gets the job done and it works. But that doesn't work in a film.

259
00:22:45.246 --> 00:22:50.686
Not really. The problem is that while the fourth wall in a stage show is the audience, the fourth

260
00:22:50.686 --> 00:22:56.046
wall in a film is the camera. And then later the audience will watch what the camera captured.

261
00:22:56.046 --> 00:23:00.126
And because of our underlying notion of cameras and how they work and what their purpose is,

262
00:23:00.126 --> 00:23:05.166
we generally expect them to record something matching close to reality. I don't mean that

263
00:23:05.166 --> 00:23:09.626
that we expect everything that we see on film to actually be capable of happening in real

264
00:23:09.626 --> 00:23:14.926
life. Like, it's not like we're all watching Dune and going, this is bullshit. Worms aren't

265
00:23:14.926 --> 00:23:16.286
actually that big.

266
00:23:16.286 --> 00:23:20.806
However, there is this sort of idea that what we're seeing in frame is something that exists

267
00:23:20.806 --> 00:23:24.926
in the world of that frame, and that the world of that frame needs to seem like enough of

268
00:23:24.926 --> 00:23:29.446
a believable world to us. It's generally why you don't see as much abstraction in

269
00:23:29.446 --> 00:23:34.026
film as you do in theatre, at least outside of art films. It's also why effects and

270
00:23:34.026 --> 00:23:39.386
props tend to get called out for not looking realistic more in film than they do in theatre.

271
00:23:39.386 --> 00:23:44.346
Unless it's like that weird bone saw inflatable that they used in Spider-Man Turn Off the Dark,

272
00:23:44.346 --> 00:23:48.666
what the fuck was that? The ways in which the language of the two mediums differ is honestly

273
00:23:48.666 --> 00:23:53.786
the root cause for a lot of the adaptational issues that you see in a lot of terrible musical

274
00:23:53.786 --> 00:23:58.986
movies. If there's any style of theatre that takes full advantage of the abstract nature of the stage,

275
00:23:58.986 --> 00:24:03.546
it's musicals, and trying to figure out how to convert that into a film with different standards

276
00:24:03.546 --> 00:24:05.966
and understandings of how everything should be presented.

One of the ways this difference manifests itself, and a way in which it's especially noticeable in Dear Evan Hansen, is the way both stories convey the passage of time. The stage musical really wants to make it clear to the audience that Evan's lie, at least at the beginning, wasn't really something he deliberately set out to create. It was him not wanting to speak up in an awkward situation and correct a pair of grieving parents, and then it snowballed out of control from there. And one of the things this show does do well is to convey the passage of time. Sets and characters often move around Evan who is the centerpiece, so once he's finished keeping up one aspect of his ruse, he's immediately onto the next thing. Evan is spending time with Zoe, and then immediately afterward, Alana is urging him to keep sharing his email exchanges with Connor. Or Evan is with his mom Heidi, and then the world moves around him, and immediately he's back visiting the Murphy family again, living in the temporary lie of a supportive, wealthy, nuclear family. In a lot of ways, this conveys the exact same feeling Evan has- that he has no control over his life, that things happen to him. But in the film, that sense of momentum is no longer present. Characters and sets can't just move around Evan to keep up that feeling of constant pressure and snowballing. Instead, when we keep cutting to him going from his house to school to the Murphy home, it becomes a lot more grounded in our minds, and a lot more clear to us that like, this sense of constant action happening to Evan isn't really what we're seeing here. There are long stretches of time between the things Evan does, and he keeps just choosing to go over and hang out at the Murphys when really, he could stop at any time. Along with the casting, and along with the musical changes, and along with the scripting changes, this is yet another reason we find it extremely difficult to relate to and sympathize with Evan, and another reason why he comes off as a fucking serial killer. The heightened, dramatic, very metaphorical tension around time and how Evan responds to it can't really work on film in the same way that it does on stage. Which means, when you're adapting it, if you want to convey that same feeling of things just snowballing out of control, you need to make certain changes to the way it's directed or what exactly happens in it in order to translate that feeling to a more grounded medium. But by and large, Dear Evan Hansen just doesn't do that, and so we end up watching and judging Evan a lot more harshly than we would when we see him on stage. This is a challenge directors face a lot when they're trying to translate metaphorical or simplified versions of a staged story onto screen. You can't necessarily create the same non-literal visual shorthand as you can on stage, but at the same time, too much realism can actually weaken what a story is trying to do. I think the perfect example of this in action is The Last Five Years. For those who don't know, The Last Five Years is a semi-autobiographical musical by Twitter name searcher Jason Robert Brown chronicling the relationship and eventual breakup of two people. Jamie, a self-absorbed asshole writer, and Kathy, a woman with anxiety and insecurity issues who needs more time and respect than what Jamie is willing to provide to her because he just didn't listen to anything and always put his needs before hers and… sorry, sorry, my co-writer Emily went through a breakup while writing this script, I don't know if you can tell. There are two things that make the last five years stand out. The first being that it's told from a non-linear perspective. Jamie's side of the story is told in chronological order, starting with the two meeting and ending with him leaving her, while Kathy's side of the story is told in reverse, starting with Jamie leaving her and ending with the two meeting for the first time. The second thing that makes it stand out is, well, the fact that it's even split up into two sides to begin with. With the exception of one number toward the middle where the two stories sync up chronologically, Jamie and Kathy are never on stage at the same time. Essentially all the songs are solos, there is no ensemble, just one of the actors on stage singing about the relationship and then when they're done they tag out and the other actor comes in to do their song. This is important to the way the last five years feels. For starters, it contributes to the feeling of disconnect between Jamie and Kathy. Considering how the musical starts with the revelation that these two won't actually end up together, having them have limited onstage interaction takes away a lot of feelings of intimacy the couple could have, and I mean that in the best of ways. It makes it especially clear, not just through the lyrics themselves but via the physical presentation of them, that there is an intense split and difference in how the two experience things. And that's another reason it works so well. By dividing the two characters up, making it so that only one of them sings to the audience at a time, it reinforces the idea that what you're being presented is simply the perspective of the person singing at the time, rather than the actual objective truth of what was going on. 00:22:15.586 --> 00:22:20.886
and kids laugh at him and take out their phones to record his embarrassment. Which is just…

275
00:22:20.886 --> 00:22:21.886
wild to me.

276
00:22:21.886 --> 00:22:26.646
Like, imagine if his speech did end up sucking and he wasn't able to turn it around. What

277
00:22:26.646 --> 00:22:32.286
would they do with that upload? Post it to r slash cringe with the title, teenager drops

278

his cue cards at suicide memorial for his best friend. Thankfully Evan didn't mess

279

up his speech, so they instead uploaded it with the title, His Best Friend Died. You won't believe

280
00:22:42.606 --> 00:22:47.246
what he did next, which is the real title that they put in the actual movie for the really sad

281
00:22:47.246 --> 00:22:52.526
emotional scene, I shit you not. Fucking choices. When this movie isn't making the worst choices

282
00:22:52.526 --> 00:22:58.766
possible, it's making the most boring ones. This film has a tendency to really, really go all in on

283
00:22:58.766 --> 00:23:04.526
shot-reverse shots, both in its musical numbers and also just in general. There are so many scenes

284
00:23:04.526 --> 00:23:09.646
that are just these long, static medium shots of the actors swapping back and forth with no

285
00:23:09.646 --> 00:23:13.646
other interesting camera choices or stage movements or anything.

286
00:23:13.646 --> 00:23:18.286
This can be seen in scenes like the new song The Anonymous Ones, but can especially be felt in the

287

way they shot Only Us. For context, this is the song where Zoe and Evan get together, with Zoe

288
00:23:23.646 --> 00:23:28.286
expressing her love for Evan and her desire to progress the relationship beyond bonding over her

289
00:23:28.286 --> 00:23:33.326
dead brother. It's the closest thing Dear Evan Hansen has to a romantic song, once you ignore

290
00:23:33.326 --> 00:23:36.086
or all the, you know, other stuff that might make it weird.

291
00:23:36.086 --> 00:23:41.126
And the movie decides to showcase these two growing closer by mainly showing them separated

292

in their own frames, away from each other and across the room.

293

I'm not sure exactly why the film does this so often.

294
00:23:48.226 --> 00:23:51.946
If I had to guess, it could be because they just struggled to figure out exactly how to

295
00:23:51.946 --> 00:23:56.866
choreograph and frame a lot of these numbers and just defaulting to the most basic option.

296

297

because yes, they did film this movie during the height of the pandemic, which means every

298
00:24:05.006 --> 00:24:05.946
shot you see on screen is a very good shot.

If there's any style of theatre that takes full advantage of the abstract nature of the stage, it's musicals, and trying to figure out how to convert that into a film with different standards and understandings of how everything should be presented  is… challenging. One of the ways this difference manifests itself, and a way in which it's especially noticeable in Dear Evan Hansen, is the way both stories convey the passage of time. For those who don't know, The Last Five Years is a semi-autobiographical musical by Twitter name searcher Jason Robert Brown chronicling the relationship and eventual breakup of two people. There are two things that make the last five years stand out. The first being that it's told from a non-linear perspective. Jamie's side of the story is told in chronological order, starting with the two meeting and ending with him leaving her, while Kathy's side of the story is told in reverse, starting with Jamie leaving her and ending with the two meeting for the first time. The second thing that makes it stand out is, well, the fact that it's even split up into two sides to begin with. With the exception of one number toward the middle where the two stories sync up chronologically, Jamie and Kathy are never on stage at the same time. Not that I would condone such a thing, but I'm just saying that trying to say you need a film adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen to immortalize Ben Platt's performance rings a bit hollow in a world where I can google blue slime tutorial and find a video of the original Broadway cast. Bootlegs especially rose to greater prominence in 2020, as with the global worldwide panini shutting down theatres, they became the only way for people to consume shows during that time. And I don't have anything to prove this, but I personally think that this also affected the way theatre companies viewed bootlegs. Beforehand, years ago, bootlegs and slime tutorials would get taken down super quickly and super easily. Someone would upload that one DVD-fab bootleg of Hamilton, if you know the one, you know the one, and you only had a few hours to watch it before it was taken down. Same with Hadestown and Dear Evan Hansen and other big productions. But now there's just a plethora of bootlegs on YouTube, with hundreds of thousands of views that have been up for months, if not years. It definitely seems like the powers that be have gotten so much more relaxed about this sort of thing, which is nice because it opens a lot more opportunities for people to experience a lot more shows. Bootlegs aren't perfect. They generally have poor visual quality, sometimes the camera won't focus on the things you want focused on, and sometimes you just can't see or hear what's going on well at all. But they can still be entertaining to watch, and in a lot of respects are still better than a lot of the film counterparts. Like, I can honestly say that I preferred watching the camcorder bootleg of Dear Evan Hansen over the $30 million film adaptation. But if the visuals, or questionable legality of bootlegs bothers you, that's fine and understandable. Watching a stage version of a show can be nice, but you might not like tracking down a version on an illicit source that's filmed on someone's potato. Well, that's where you get to one of the other, more interesting recent developments- pro recordings. Professional recordings of stage shows aren't anything new- they've technically been around for a while. But they were generally pretty rare. Much like film adaptations, a lot of theatre companies don't want to have an outside version of the show that could potentially disincentivise someone from actually seeing it live. As such, pro recordings were generally only released for shows that had been going on for a while or that weren't going to be open for much longer. It took around 20 or so years for popular stage shows like Cats and Rent and Phantom of the Opera to finally get professional recordings. Although, pretty much every show has has a proper camera recording of it, New York Public Library has access to it, it's just that most of us are not allowed to go in there and watch those things. Fun fact. That being said, pro recordings have their own unique problem. Part of the reason why you still saw film adaptations more than pro recordings is because for a while, there wasn't really a good way to distribute pro recordings at least not in a way that would maximize profits Recordings of live shows and concerts don usually get theatrical runs which meant for a while the only method for releasing pro recordings was direct and direct Which is fine But well direct video stuff used to come with this stigma of being of lesser quality than theatrical counterparts. And it would almost certainly mean not making as much money. There was some hope that this could change though. Back in 2016, renowned lip-biter Lin-Manuel Miranda made sure to get a full HD professional recording of Hamilton done with the original Broadway cast. The goal was to keep the recording in storage for a little while before debuting it to the public. And sure enough, the mouse himself Disney bought the rights to it for $75 million with plans to give it a full theatrical release on October 15th, 2021. And then, like, the world shut down. And so instead, it was retooled into a Disney Plus exclusive, and its release pushed way, way up to July 3rd, 2020. And it was a huge, huge success. Now, there's a lot of discourse about Hamilton, discourse that is banned from this channel because I do not want to get into it, but I'll say this, the Hamilton Pro recording does a very, very good job replicating the energy of the stage show. Whatever you like about the stage show is basically still here, and if you like Hamilton, you'll like the pro recording, and if you've never experienced Hamilton, then you'll get a quality initial experience with this. And most importantly, this thing was fucking massive. Streaming companies don't generally release viewer numbers, but going by estimates, Hamilton was viewed by around 22 million people in its first month of release, which is a stupidly high number. It was the second most watched straight to streaming title that year, right behind Wonder Woman 1984. This is really interesting because it showed that, under the right circumstances, audiences are 100% willing to watch a recorded version of a stage show rather than a full film adaptation. Furthermore, it also showed that streaming platforms are a good place to distribute these sort of things. Much like the way it's easy to stumble across and watch a musical on YouTube without much personal investment, people can stumble upon shows they're curious about on a subscription streaming platform and watch them. And the demand for such things is there and huge. It's difficult to say how Hamilton's streaming version success will affect other productions going forward. Not all shows were lucky enough to have filmed a performance years before the lockdown, so there weren't a lot of immediate copycats trying to imitate its success. We have seen one, though. Before the pandemic, there were plans to adapt Come From Away into a feature film, which is just… not a great idea if you've seen that show. Like, a large part of its appeal is experimenting with the theatre format and its ensemble and the pacing and intensity of a live show. Once the pandemic happened though, these plans basically evaporated as it was impossible to make any progress on the film version and interest in the project dropped. However, upon seeing the success of Hamilton on Disney+, it was decided that instead of a film adaptation, they would instead change course and create a pro recording exclusively for Apple TV. And while I don't know how successful it was, because obviously Come From Away is nowhere near as popular as Hamilton, I can say that the pro recording is pretty good and definitely worth a watch, and I'm pretty confident in saying that it's better than any film adaptation of the material would have been. It'll be interesting to see if more shows start doing this. There's a whole debate to be had about streaming exclusive content, and I know it can be annoying, but I would rather have Hulu get exclusive rights to a Hadestown Pro recording than have to sit through a Universal Pictures film version. I think for a lot of shows, this method is a lot better and leads to a better quality product. And with Broadway's already existing issues with accessibility, I think this is a very good middle ground, and I would love to see more Pro recordings get released in the future. Dear Evan Hansen is bad. I don't think anyone here is going to debate me on that, especially after watching two hours of me ramble about it. It's a dull, depressing, plodding mess of a movie that's uninteresting at best, potentially tasteless at worst. But as I sat there and watched it and made fun of it with my co-writer Emily, I realized that Dear Evan Hansen itself isn't the problem. Rather, it's a symptom of a much worse disease. Musical movies are a strange art form, and one that's been in an awkward zone recently. After their resurgence to prominence in the early 2000s with Chicago and Moulin Rouge, it's been an up and down battle between films that understand the assignment and films that don't. And it's really interesting to me that a time where we're getting really good musical films like In the Heights and Annette also gave us such films as Amazon Prime's Cinderella and Dear Evan Hansen. And considering how we're about to get things like West Side Story and The Wicked Movie for real this time, it's tempting to look at exactly why certain musical adaptations do and don't work so you know whether or not to get your hopes up about the Wicked Movie that's happening certainly for real this time, guys. I went into this video with the simple mission statement of trashing Dear Evan Hansen because it's a bad and easily mockable movie, but the more I dug through it and the more I thought about it, the more I realized that my frustrations with Dear Evan Hansen as a film don't come from a place of hate, but out of love.

I love musicals. I love them a lot. I think that they can be fun and incredibly compelling works of art that can entertain and enlighten. It's the combination of the art of music and the art of dance and the art of cinema into a beautiful amalgamation. And that's why it's so disappointing when that combination comes out looking more like a clusterfucked homunculus. During the writing process, after this script had already been mostly written, I learned the news that Stephen Sondheim had died. I don't know if you can tell, just from the absolute nerding out that happened in this video, but Into the Woods is my absolute favorite musical of all time. The characters, the musicality, the writing, the themes, everything about it resonates with me so hard. And so many people have that feeling with so many of Sondheim's works, all of which I honestly love. So much of what he's written has resonated with so many people and it all an absolutely incredible testament not only to what this man has created throughout his life but also what he created specifically within the medium of theatre His work is some Broadway Broadway and it all such an incredible way of showcasing what you can do with musicals that you can't always do as effectively with other mediums. When I saw Sweeney Todd in like an off-Broadway stage they set up to be a pie shop, the characters walking and living and dying all around you and in the same space as you, I felt so pulled in and immersed in a way I've never quite experienced in another medium. When you listen to a song like Not Getting Married Today and you hear everyone sing at the same time, the different vocal styles and tempos and lyrics reflecting how their very discordant mental states come together, you feel so pulled in not just by theatre but by the fact that it's theatre. This was never intended to be a Sondheim video, but honestly, so much of what Sondheim has put into the world of theatre is both a testament and a blessing to the very nature of the medium. It's hard to say what path movie musicals will take from this point on. The box office failures of Cats, Dear Evan Hansen, and unfortunately In the Heights, mixed with the absurd success of Hamilton's pro recording could lead to a drastic shift in how these projects get made, and if we even get theatrical film adaptations at all. In a lot of respects right now, a lot of hope is resting on West Side Story and Wicked to hopefully pick up that slack and prove that there's still an audience out there for the musical movie. It's a format that has promise, and as we've seen throughout some of the examples in the video, can be done well, on rare occasions even in ways that are better or more interesting than their stage counterparts. But these films are so often made without a true understanding of what a musical is and what it should be, and what parts of it can be altered to still create an interesting piece of art. One of the things we see a lot with projects like the Dear Evan Hansen movie is a rejection of what makes musicals musicals. Of strong choreography, of emotionally explosive musical numbers, of line delivery that's alive and a little bit exaggerated. And as someone who loves the things that make up what a musical is, that's a little sad to see. And that's why honestly, if the rise of professionally shot stage musicals does indeed end up overshadowing the current trend of film adaptations, I'm gonna be pretty okay with that. In all fairness though, the real reason for that has nothing to do with anything I've said over the past like two hours. The real reason is that in this hypothetical future, we may never again have to see a movie musical that has James Corden in it. In case you couldn't tell, one of my favorite things is looking at random pieces of media and trying to work out what sort of storytelling lessons we might be able to take away from them, even ones we didn't necessarily expect. In this video, I didn't just want to talk about Dear Evan Hansen so much as use it as a case study for the medium of musicals in general. formatted_chat.summary: The speaker discusses the musical Dear Evan Hansen and its recent film adaptation. They analyze what went wrong with the movie and how it failed to translate the stage show to the screen. The speaker also touches on the trend of musical adaptations and the challenges of bringing Broadway shows to the big screen. The film adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen has several issues, including poor casting choices, particularly with Ben Platt playing Evan Hansen at an age that doesn't align with the character's high school age. The film also struggles with translating the stage production to screen, making it hard to empathize with Evan's character. The music in the film is also criticized, with added songs feeling shoehorned and generic. The adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen for film has several issues, primarily with the cutting of certain songs and changes to the script. The speaker argues that these changes, such as cutting the song 'Does Anybody Have a Map?' and replacing 'Good For You' with a two-minute argument scene, detract from the story and characters. The film's attempts to address criticisms of the stage show, like making Evan admit to lying on social media, fall flat. The speaker also criticizes the film's direction and cinematography, saying they don't effectively translate the stage show to screen. The speaker discusses the difficulties of adapting stage musicals to film, using Dear Evan Hansen and The Last Five Years as examples. They highlight the differences between the two mediums, particularly in terms of how time and space are conveyed, and how musical numbers are staged and shot. The speaker argues that the film adaptations of these musicals often struggle to translate the unique qualities of the stage productions to the screen. The film adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen has been criticized for its awkward and uncomfortable musical numbers, poor directing, and drastic tonal shift from the stage show. The movie's attempts to ground the story in realism come across as forced and unnatural, leading to a dull and depressing viewing experience. The speaker argues that the film's problems are not unique to Dear Evan Hansen, but rather a symptom of a larger issue with musical film adaptations. The speaker discusses their love for musicals, specifically highlighting Stephen Sondheim's works, and analyzes the current state of movie musicals, citing the box office failures of Cats, Dear Evan Hansen, and In the Heights. They express concern that film adaptations often lack the essence of what makes musicals great, such as strong choreography and emotionally explosive numbers. Basically, when you enter a staged space, you implicitly recognize that elements of it are going to be larger than life and that these things will act as stand-ins for different things. Which is why, for example, an older actor can act as a representation of a younger character, and it doesn't necessarily matter very much. Half the ensemble members in Matilda are children, and half of them, the ones doing the more complicated choreography are adults, and it doesn't matter or look weird because we're pulled into the metaphorical space of Matilda.

Or even going outside age. The costumes in The Lion King aren't just fursuits designed to look like hyper-realistic lions, they're a mix of literal masks and puppeteering to convey the image of the animal they're representing, but also just clothing and costumes that get at the character's personality and feeling rather than an attempt to look like a literal lion. How a character looks in a Broadway show is often non-literal, and that's recognized and understood by audiences. So if Ben Platt is a bit older than he used to be in the role, it's not really that big of a deal because we're already suspending visual disbelief by stepping into the space.

The second reason is a lot more basic. Generally speaking, audience members at live shows aren't seeing actors in high definition. They'll be seated many feet away, even in the best best most expensive seats and sometimes an entire room away if you in the nosebleeds It just a lot less weird and noticeable for a somewhat older actor to stand on stage live than it is when you getting these close on their face in a movie theatre and every single wrinkle is on full display. Film is not only a typically much more literal representation of what we're seeing, which is why if they make a Matilda movie musical, adults playing elementary school students and hanging out with them on screen would look really fucking weird, but you also just get a much better look at people, seeing them up close, and in a much more grounded and realistic setting.

So when you're making a movie, whether it's with age or other physical traits about the musical characters, you need to be a lot more careful about the realism of whatever it is you're depicting. If you don't want whatever you're depicting in film to involve that kind of realism, it's going to take a lot more active effort because otherwise that's typically just the default of that medium. And when this falls apart for any reason, it's much more noticeable and problematic in film. Unless you're doing something like Mamma Mia, which just doesn't give a shit and doesn't pretend to give a shit, if your actors look slightly off for the part, it's incredibly obvious.

Meryl Streep is obviously an amazing actor, but the way she was cast and styled in something like Into the Woods, which is my favourite musical and I feel very strongly about this, just doesn't work in the the more toned down, grounded approach it has on film compared to stage. Look at Bernadette Peters' costuming and prosthetics used to make her look like this cartoonish old witch lady, and you can see how big and dramatic that shift later is when she's transformed back into a beautiful woman. That big shift probably wouldn't work as well in live action film just in general because of the cartoonishness of it, but they try to resolve this in the film with a much more realistic witch, and that makes the big transformation look like very… nothing. Like, she just has neater hair and slightly fewer wrinkles and bags under her eyes.

She didn't need to send everyone in her little magic village on a fetch quest for beauty, she could just brush her hair and put a bit of foundation on and she would look the exact same. And the fact that we are looking at her up close throughout every scene she's in in this film means that we can tell, extremely fucking well, the differences in that transformation are, and so necessarily we judge it in the context of its realism. In terms of casting for the rest of Dear Evan Hansen, it's for the most part fine. There were some criticisms that I frankly don't feel the most qualified to go super in depth to about Amandla Stenberg's casting as Alana, as often it is a dark-skinned actor playing that role on stage and there aren't a lot of roles for dark-skinned women.

But other than their casting, everyone is ranging from passable to pretty good at their job. Amy Adams and Julianne Moore are doing their best despite their reduced roles in the show, Caitlin Dever is as good an actor as any as Zoe, and the Connor and the Jared are mostly fine. This is a cast that theoretically should be able to carry the story despite the unfortunate inclusion as a poorly styled Ben Platt of Evan. But so much of the story still hinges on Evan.

Very much, more than it is a story about Connor or Evan's mom or the Murphys or anyone else. This is about Evan and his own mental health. And so when virtually everything he does in this show comes off as deranged because we no longer understand him as a mentally ill teen who stumbled into the lie, and when we are therefore constantly pulled out of getting any real investment in the story because we're distracted by how just fucking weird and out of place Evan Hansen looks, we can't necessarily get as invested in any parts of the story at all in the way that we could on stage. But even in scenes that aren't largely about Evan, like in the Requiem scene, we still can't get fully invested in the story, and that's because the faults of this film go beyond just who is acting in it.

Another really key element to making Broadway work on film is what you do with the music, And the film unfortunately fucks this up too. So something that's just become accepted as a thing that happens when musicals get adapted to film is that, generally speaking, two things are going to happen. You are going to lose some of the songs from the stage version, and there is always going to be at least one new song written specifically for the movie musical. So for example, you have Suddenly, the one that Valjean sings to Gazette when they're the wagon together, or you have all the new songs in those live action Disney adaptations like Evermore and Beauty and the Beast, or the Girlboss song in Aladdin, or fucking Beautiful Ghosts from the Cats movie.

And generally speaking, this is just something you're going to have to expect in a film adaptation. And in all fairness, these aren't always bad songs. But these are generally known for being kind of forgettable and kind of… cynical. To have pop covers and be streamed all the time, to sound inspirational and make money, rather than to actually fit well into the show. That's why most of the time when you go see a movie musical, even if you're not super familiar with the original music, it tends to be incredibly easy to point out which song was added later.

This is a tough position to tackle when you're adapting a musical for the screen. On top of being chock full of songs, another thing about Broadway musicals is that they tend to be very long. You tend to be in for a two and a half hour experience, a little less without the intermission, and the idea is that you are going to get your money's worth. So when you're adapting something like that to screen, it's not surprising that, oftentimes, certain songs are just going to have to get cut.

Or sometimes there are songs that might not necessarily work as well on stage as they do in a film. I'm gonna talk to you in a bit about an entire musical that just probably never should have been a film because there's no real good way imaginable that you could have pulled it off. Or sometimes certain songs are just bad. The fact that the song Mooning isn't in the Grease movie is not some horrible travesty.

But these things don't just affect the cast recording or the numbers or any of that. You can't get rid of or modify songs that having an effect on the story, and a lot of the time that effect is negative. Generally speaking, music isn't thrust haphazardously into a show with no consideration for when a song should exist or why. Unless a musical is totally sung through like Les Mis or Hamilton, songs are placed at specific points in the story, with the most common adage about it being you sing when you can no longer speak.

These tend to be points of heightened emotion that are either personally important to the characters or just important to the broader story. So, for example, in Dear Evan Hansen, the song Requiem isn't just in there because it sounds pretty. Requiem is about all three of Connor's surviving relatives having different perspectives on how to grieve Connor, things none of them are willing or able to talk about with one another yet. So watching each of them, on their own, singing their verses about their complicated feelings on their son's death, furthers our understanding of these characters in a way you can't necessarily get with dialogue.
The song is really important, and it's important that that is a song. Or take the Into the Woods movie. God, I hate that movie. I hate that movie so much.

Horrible adaptation of absolutely incredible source material. In terms of toning down a lot of the themes and darker elements of the show and just making it like, ooooh, pretty fairy tale, they also cut the entire subplot with the baker and his father and most of the Rapunzel stuff. So for those of you who haven't seen Into the Woods, which is I'm assuming most people, one of the themes is that the witch in this story, who is one of the best characters in anything ever and I love her, basically locks Rapunzel, her adoptive daughter- I guess adoptive is a weird word- her kidnapped daughter- in a tower for most of her life, something we later see in the show explicitly traumatizes her and makes her unable to interact normally with other people and later even leads to her dying. This is unsurprisingly not in the film because it is a Disney movie and they're not going to kill off one of their princesses, so she's just barely in it and then she just leaves.

And the baker, one of the leads, is also struggling to process the death of his wife while also parenting a newborn baby and is tempted to just walk away from the responsibility of being a parent. And then he has this song conversation with his own father, who did exactly that, walked away from being a parent, and it's kind of about breaking the cycle and making the choice to be better, and again, really important that this is a song. The film, by cutting these songs out, and therefore by cutting both subplots, are essentially erasing an entire theme of the show, which is largely about how we are shaped by the way we're raised, and the way trauma can be passed on, and our responsibility to our children. So at the end of the movie, when they're all singing like, be careful the things you say, children will listen, it really rings hollow because like, what the fuck are they talking about?

What does this have to do with anything we just watched in this movie? Why are we singing about how we raise our children all of a sudden? This is especially salient given that the show's creator, Stephen Sondheim, was himself a survivor of parental abuse and emotional neglect, and large portions of the story are explicitly a reflection on this and on the consequences on our own childhoods. In many ways, this theme is the show.

My point is that cutting songs from musicals is often a necessary thing, but it's also a very risky one. You risk either taking moments of heightened emotion and reducing their importance to the story, or just disregarding key themes from the narrative you're trying to tell. All this doesn't mean you should never cut certain numbers from a show, but rather that you need to be conscious about what you're cutting and why, and what, if anything, you replace it with. And once again, Dear Evan Hansen does not do that.

So, to break in a glove, the shitty, boring song that has Evan, who never really knew his dad, bonding with Connor's conservative wasp dad gets cut, which is fine, no one liked that song anyway. But they also cut the opening song of the musical, the one that sets the tone for the entire thing, Does Anybody Have a Map? And this song is basically showcasing Evan's mom and Connor's mom at the same time, and their own struggles trying to connect with their kids. It serves a few purposes.

For one, it centers Evan's mother Heidi as an important character whose own struggles and worries we see beyond just being a mom whose job is mom. It lets us see more of Connor and how he relates to his family and what his home life was like, which is important given how little Connor as Connor actually features in this show. It establishes a central theme of the musical, which is that as much as the Hanson family and the Murphy family exist within different structures and different socioeconomic classes, their struggles with their children are fundamentally the same. The moms are singing the same words at the same time for a reason.

And cutting it, instead opening right with Evan singing waving through a window, really reduces the importance of these themes. Also, just from a nitpicky theatre nerd perspective, you don't open with the I Want song. The I Want song is almost always the second, or sometimes third song in the show, because generally speaking, songs that exist to establish the world and the stakes come first for a reason. You can't have a How Far I'll Go without having a Where You Are.

You can't I have confidence without how do you solve a problem like Maria. You need to establish who or what the world is before it matters what a character wants or feels within its constraints. Just fucking hell. But in particular, the way this, and the film in general, cuts down on Evan's relationship with his mom is a real problem.

Because on top of cutting Does Anybody Have a Map, they also cut Good For You, one of the best and actually most important songs in the show Good For You serves a crucial narrative purpose At this point we reach the part in the story where Evan is starting to get wrapped up in his lies. He's moved from being someone to whom the lies kind of accidentally happened, to someone who is actively making the choice to keep telling them, because the benefits he gets from it are making him feel good. His relationship with Zoe is going great. He keeps going over to the Murphys' house and basically treating them as surrogate parents, and as a result, he's neglecting his role in the charity he helped start, he's neglecting his friendship with Jared, and he's neglecting his relationship with his actual mother.

The Murphys even offer to pay for him to go off to university- something that makes his own mom Heidi feel extremely embarrassed and belittled. And Evan is extremely on board with this- something that we as the audience know is built on the lies he is now actively choosing to continually tell to this family. And so Good For You is the number where Alana, Jared, and most importantly Heidi are basically singing this to him. They're talking about how Evan is treating them as disposable.

How he's only being with these people to the extent that he can use them for personal gain. Jared, with whom he fabricates the emails, is only being treated as a vessel for Evan to keep lying. His mom is someone to be discarded in favor of this new surrogate family he's found for himself. Alana is left with the burden of maintaining a charity based on Evan's lies all by herself.

The song is important for several reasons. For one, it's one of the few times people's feelings other than Evan's are explicitly centered in the voice of the show. We get to see, viscerally, how Evan's actions are affecting other people all at once. It's a good way of showing how in-deep Evan has gotten.

They are trying in this song to urge him back to doing the right thing, and it isn't working. There's even a section that shows how desperately Evan has dug himself into this hole, and the fact that he doesn't really seem to want to get out of it. And it also, once again, deepens the importance of the character of Heidi. She's more than just a mom figure who exists solely to provide emotional comfort to Evan.

It shows the way she is deeply affected by his actions. And even just from an Evan standpoint, Heidi is a very humanizing part of Evan's story. Even while he is behaving very unethically, the strong ties between Evan and his mom make Evan a more sympathetic person. It makes his breakdown, where he just needs his mom to comfort him, where he needs a love that is unconditional, feel much more real.

And to reduce Heidi to a very limited character whose only job is just to be mom and to replace everything in Good For You with like a two minute argument scene is strongly to this show's detriment. There's also… another song that they technically add toward the end, and I'll get to that one in a second because that's more of a storytelling issue than a music issue. But on the whole, the way they chose to distribute these songs, what was kept and what was cut in the story, really acted to its detriment. And I think this, and other failures to cut things properly like we saw in Into the Woods, reflects an improper understanding of what a musical is and what a musical is fundamentally supposed to do.

I did a whole video on this as it pertained to musical episodes of non-musical TV shows, but essentially, musical numbers are a very deliberate choice that serve a unique narrative purpose. And so you need to be equally careful and equally deliberate when cutting things out or bringing new elements in. And we very much did not get that here. In terms of musicals being much longer than their film counterparts most of the time, that adaptational element also tends to demand changes to the actual story.

And that's, again, just a necessary thing. Film is a different medium and has different focus and different time constraints, so it's not necessarily a problem that, say, there's a fuckton of new dialogue in In the Heights, or that Tracy doesn't go to jail in the Hairspray movie, or actually a very good change in Hairspray was having Inez win the competition instead of Tracy, scripting changes are natural in shows, especially when there were issues in the original, or just things that wouldn't translate well to film. And that's the thing- Dear Evan Hansen has a lot of problems, and it's already faced a lot of criticism for how it's handled its subject matter. So the film definitely served as an opportunity to reframe some of the elements in the original that didn't necessarily work to its advantage.

And to its credit, it does try. It does attempt to reconcile with some of the more criticized parts of its stage counterpart. Unfortunately, it seems to have just worsened every single aspect of it. But perhaps the most blatant scripting change is to the ending. Additionally, there's also the criticism that the stage musical isn't really about Connor, and instead uses the suicide of this teenager primarily as a plot device to explore other characters. So the filmmakers decided to change the ending of the movie in order to essentially address both criticisms at the same time. And it doesn't really help, like… at all. So in the stage show, the Murphys find out about what Evan did, but they all keep it secret.

The film tries to fix this by having Evan admit to lying about everything on his Instagram page. I was never friends with Connor Murphy. I lied.

Repeatedly. And then, in order to hopefully gain a more accurate perspective of Connor, he messages anyone he can on Connor's Facebook page until he finds someone who went to rehab with Connor, who gives Evan a video of Connor performing a song he wrote while in the clinic. Evan then distributes a USB containing the footage to Connor's loved ones and people involved in the Connor project, and that's when we then time skip a year later to the Apple Orchard conversation with Zoe and Evan. On the surface, this seems like an okay change, but in actual execution, it fixes… basically nothing.

Part of the problem is that in the grand scheme of things, nothing about the ending is fundamentally different. She just fucking dies in the movie because it's film. You can just tell your actor to go home. But in the musical, she pops up as a ghost. She's Veronica's conscience.

But in all seriousness, what this means is that even though we're not seeing the actual Connor in life and in action, and we are seeing Evan's internal conception of Connor, his presence is still felt throughout the show. People talk about him, sure, but we don't really see him nor do we get a lot of interesting details about him or a sense of who he is The way they feature Connor in the film he might as well have just been a lamp that broke and shattered that everyone is now sad about That why this changed ending with the new song rings so hollow They took out a significant portion of this character's presence and identity from the show and replaced it with a generic acoustic radio hit.

It makes the film feel less like it's trying to tell the story of Dear Evan Hansen, and more like the film is supposed to be an apology for the story of Dear Evan Hansen. But not even a good apology, one of those ones where someone is like, I am very sorry if you were offended by my words.

The way that the film is written, the changes and alterations it makes to the source material, which already had issues to begin with, makes the film seem way more hollow and way more mean and impersonal than its stage counterpart.
