So, um, how good is Evan Hansen's directing?

Perhaps one of the most important parts of a stage-to-screen conversion is one of the ones that you don't really think about. And admittedly, that's because most people don't think about it in general. Cinematography, staging, and blocking are some of the great invisible magics of the art form. Things like acting and music and dialogue are all flashy and in your face.

They're things you can easily notice and observe and comment on regardless of your knowledge of the medium or any greater theory. It's pretty easy to tell how a certain casting choice affects the film, or if a song is performed well, or if a line of dialogue is good or bad. But generally speaking, things like blocking and cinematography are sort of meant to be invisible. Unless something is actively trying to be noticeable, chances are you aren't going to notice, the same way you might not notice exactly what you're doing with your hands in a certain moment, or where you are relative to the door in your room.

It's also the moment where a lot of movie musicals really, really mess up, especially recently. You see, as we've kind of talked about throughout the video, film and theatre are two different mediums and by extension have two different languages. Things that work on stage won't necessarily work on screen and vice versa. A lot of this is a difference in perceived realism.

In a stage production, you don't necessarily need to believe that the space people are occupying is a real space because, well, you'd know it's not. You're there observing a performance. You are watching people perform in a box in front of you. They exist in the same physical space that you do.

That means that a lot of the staging and production of stage shows are more… abstract, I guess is the best word. They can play around more with the environment, such as how Hamilton's set is a mostly static wooden room with a few props brought in every now and then. You can play with time, like having a character finish one scene and then transition into another scene without that character leaving the stage at all, or anything else that would give the theoretical idea of a scene ending. Think of how Come From Away has most of its cast on stage for the entirety of its show and just transitions effortlessly between moment to moment.

But I think one of the most important things unique to theatre is the way that a character interacts with the fourth wall. The fourth wall thing is quite interesting because it's a small matter that really does have a large effect on the overall perception of the work. For those who don't know, the fourth wall in a stage production refers to the fourth wall that would exist in a set. Considering how theatre has to be observable and cheated out toward an audience, rooms can't be closed and contained the same way they are in real life.

So a room in a stage show has a back wall, two side walls, and nothing else. What would be the fourth wall is the audience. And in a stage show, you can easily play with that. Because there is the unavoidable perception that this is all being performed to a crowd, you can simply have your actors, well, perform to the crowd.

I don't necessarily mean direct interactions, like calling out to them or mingling with them the way a musician might at a concert, though that certainly could happen, but it's more that because of the fact that you're aware you're being performed to, the actor, if they wanted to, could just stand there and, well, perform to you. No need for a lot of stage business, or sometimes even a background. You can just have the characters sing to the crowd amongst an empty backdrop and you're fine and it gets the job done and it works. But that doesn't work in a film.

Not really. The problem is that while the fourth wall in a stage show is the audience, the fourth wall in a film is the camera. And then later the audience will watch what the camera captured. And because of our underlying notion of cameras and how they work and what their purpose is, we generally expect them to record something matching close to reality.

I don't mean that that we expect everything that we see on film to actually be capable of happening in real life. Like, it's not like we're all watching Dune and going, this is bullshit. Worms aren't actually that big. However, there is this sort of idea that what we're seeing in frame is something that exists in the world of that frame, and that the world of that frame needs to seem like enough of a believable world to us.

It's generally why you don't see as much abstraction in film as you do in theatre, at least outside of art films. It's also why effects and props tend to get called out for not looking realistic more in film than they do in theatre. Unless it's like that weird bone saw inflatable that they used in Spider-Man Turn Off the Dark, what the fuck was that? The ways in which the language of the two mediums differ is honestly the root cause for a lot of the adaptational issues that you see in a lot of terrible musical movies.

If there's any style of theatre that takes full advantage of the abstract nature of the stage, it's musicals, and trying to figure out how to convert that into a film with different standards and understandings of how everything should be presented is… challenging. One of the ways this difference manifests itself, and a way in which it's especially noticeable in Dear Evan Hansen, is the way both stories convey the passage of time. The stage musical really wants to make it clear to the audience that Evan's lie, at least at the beginning, wasn't really something he deliberately set out to create. It was him not wanting to speak up in an awkward situation and correct a pair of grieving parents, and then it snowballed out of control from there.

And one of the things this show does do well is to convey the passage of time. Sets and characters often move around Evan who is the centerpiece, so once he's finished keeping up one aspect of his ruse, he's immediately onto the next thing. Evan is spending time with Zoe, and then immediately afterward, Alana is urging him to keep sharing his email exchanges with Connor. Or Evan is with his mom Heidi, and then the world moves around him, and immediately he's back visiting the Murphy family again, living in the temporary lie of a supportive, wealthy, nuclear family.

In a lot of ways, this conveys the exact same feeling Evan has- that he has no control over his life, that things happen to him. But in the film, that sense of momentum is no longer present. Characters and sets can't just move around Evan to keep up that feeling of constant pressure and snowballing. Instead, when we keep cutting to him going from his house to school to the Murphy home, it becomes a lot more grounded in our minds, and a lot more clear to us that like, this sense of constant action happening to Evan isn't really what we're seeing here.

There are long stretches of time between the things Evan does, and he keeps just choosing to go over and hang out at the Murphys when really, he could stop at any time. Along with the casting, and along with the musical changes, and along with the scripting changes, this is yet another reason we find it extremely difficult to relate to and sympathize with Evan, and another reason why he comes off as a fucking serial killer. The heightened, dramatic, very metaphorical tension around time and how Evan responds to it can't really work on film in the same way that it does on stage. Which means, when you're adapting it, if you want to convey that same feeling of things just snowballing out of control, you need to make certain changes to the way it's directed or what exactly happens in it in order to translate that feeling to a more grounded medium.

But by and large, Dear Evan Hansen just doesn't do that, and so we end up watching and judging Evan a lot more harshly than we would when we see him on stage. This is a challenge directors face a lot when they're trying to translate metaphorical or simplified versions of a staged story onto screen. You can't necessarily create the same non-literal visual shorthand as you can on stage, but at the same time, too much realism can actually weaken what a story is trying to do. I think the perfect example of this in action is The Last Five Years.

For those who don't know, The Last Five Years is a semi-autobiographical musical by Twitter name searcher Jason Robert Brown chronicling the relationship and eventual breakup of two people. Jamie, a self-absorbed asshole writer, and Kathy, a woman with anxiety and insecurity issues who needs more time and respect than what Jamie is willing to provide to her because he just didn't listen to anything and always put his needs before hers and… sorry, sorry, my co-writer Emily went through a breakup while writing this script, I don't know if you can tell. There are two things that make the last five years stand out. The first being that it's told from a non-linear perspective.

Jamie's side of the story is told in chronological order, starting with the two meeting and ending with him leaving her, while Kathy's side of the story is told in reverse, starting with Jamie leaving her and ending with the two meeting for the first time. The second thing that makes it stand out is, well, the fact that it's even split up into two sides to begin with. With the exception of one number toward the middle where the two stories sync up chronologically, Jamie and Kathy are never on stage at the same time. Essentially all the songs are solos, there is no ensemble, just one of the actors on stage singing about the relationship and then when they're done they tag out and the other actor comes in to do their song.

This is important to the way the last five years feels. For starters, it contributes to the feeling of disconnect between Jamie and Kathy. Considering how the musical starts with the revelation that these two won't actually end up together, having them have limited onstage interaction takes away a lot of feelings of intimacy the couple could have, and I mean that in the best of ways. It makes it especially clear, not just through the lyrics themselves but via the physical presentation of them, that there is an intense split and difference in how the two experience things.

And that's another reason it works so well. By dividing the two characters up, making it so that only one of them sings to the audience at a time, it reinforces the idea that what you're being presented is simply the perspective of the person singing at the time, rather than the actual objective truth of what was going on. Theoretically speaking, the point of the last five years is that by showing how each person saw the good and bad parts of that relationship, you understand both people's strengths and flaws, and also how they both contributed to the marriage not working. I say theoretically.

Jamie does a lot more blatantly terrible things throughout the show which are easier to point to and go, yeah, that's pretty fucked up. But for the most part, it does work out. Kathy will sing about frustrations with her career and feeling like Jamie is neglecting her and her interests, and then Jamie will come and sing about how hard it is to try and support her and be hit with a brick wall. Kathy will sing about how Jamie's success makes him too busy and makes her feel neglected, while Jamie will sing about how stressful trying to manage being a successful author is, and how terrible it can feel to have his wife seemingly judge him for trying to advance his career.

It's some honestly really interesting stuff, and despite some flaws and warts, The Last 5 Years is generally a good stage show, and I do recommend checking it out. But then in 2014, they decided to do a movie adaptation of it for… some reason. The film, starring Anna Kendrick and Jeremy Jordan showcases a lot of the issues that come up with translating a work like this to film And the thing that makes it so interesting is that there really isn anything garishly bad with the directing choices Yeah there a few things here and there that I can nitpick about such as the way they did Nobody Needs to Know, but overall, this isn't something like a Tom Hooper situation where it's just piles and piles of terrible decisions. Generally speaking, the directing is… fine.

The camera choices are a good fit for what they're going for. The switch between timelines and perspectives is made as clear as you could in film. The musical numbers are done with the energy that you'd want to have. There's no real egregious, oh, you decided to do this scene this way moment.

But yet the film just doesn't really work. And the reason why it doesn't work feels less because of any particularly bad choices and more just the differences in the medium. Because once again, we go back to that difference in the abstract versus literal. On stage, you can get away with only two actors splitting time on stage in a set that's just a single table and a bookshelf.

But that wouldn't really work in a film. If you tried that, it would feel too experimental, and too much like you just pointed a camera at a stage show. And the more complicated your set design gets, the weirder and more awkward it's going to feel to have a single actor belt a number in it without anybody else present, especially if the song is theoretically being sung to someone. So because of this, the movie basically disregards the only one actor on stage at a time setup.

Both of them are on screen together for a large part of the movie, there's a whole bunch of extras in each scene now, and in general, the film is shot and staged much like a conventional movie. This should theoretically make the show work better as a film, but no, not really. It's honestly a lot more awkward, the film didn't really make any real changes to the script or lyrics or any of the songs. Nothing substantial at least, they're all still written as, basically, solos meant to be performed more at air than at living people.

And because they're now being performed at other characters rather than at air, you get these honestly sort of uncomfortable scenes where a person will be singing to the other actor who has no choice but to just sit there and watch and try to come up with proper facial reactions. They did add some bonus dialogue to help balance it out and make it feel less one-sided, but it still sticks out really, really poorly. The end result is a film that didn't do anything egregiously wrong, but still feels like a significant downgrade over its stage version. Even if you don't mind the strange way the songs play out in the film, losing the uniqueness of the one-person-at-a-time staging does ruin a lot of of the show's impact.

It changes the way you see the two characters. It changes the way you see the two events unfold. In the play, what you're supposed to be seeing is a biased, one-sided perspective, and the staging reinforced that. But the film being shot more conventionally means that, theoretically, you're seeing an objective, reliable perspective.

It really breaks a lot of what the play is going for, and what makes it so unique in the first place, and it's not necessarily because of directorial choices, but rather just because the medium is so different that I can't imagine the last five years working on screen at all without it just being essentially a recording of the stage show. And honestly, what we can take away from the last five years' problems being adapted to film can be applied pretty easily to Dear Evan Hansen, because it also struggles with this. The difference being that the issues are less because of the format of the musical, and legit just the direction being overall pretty shit. Dear Evan Hansen is a lot more conventional of a stage show than the last five years.

It follows the standard beats you'd expect from a stage musical. Opening number, brief scene of dialogue, next musical number, that's an I Want song, scene of dialogue, musical number, dialogue, ensemble number, etc. There's nothing about the way Dear Evan Hansen is structured that makes it significantly different than your average Disney musical when you get down to it. So translating it to film wouldn't necessarily be easy, but it isn't impossible.

But oh god, talk about making essentially every wrong choice you possibly could. There's been this recent trend of musical movies that are seemingly ashamed to be musical movies, made by directors who don't really understand the genre or how to film it. Tom Hooper's Les Mis wasn't the first film to fall under this category, but it's certainly the most notable. Films in this category are generally made by prestige-slash-award-centric directors who will say that they're trying to approach the musical with a sort of grounded feel which just… no.

Like even the most downbeat of musicals is larger than life. The basis of the style itself involves people feeling so much emotion that they have to sing about it. Saying you want to make a grounded and realistic musical is like saying you want to make a subdued opera or a good video game music cover band. It's a fundamental misunderstanding of what material you're working with.

And yes, it is true that Dear Evan Hansen is more grounded than a lot of its stage contemporaries. This isn't a Hadestown or even a Hamilton. There's no elaborate dance sequences or complex musicality. Like I said before, it's basically your standard musical setup of dialogue followed by song followed by dialogue, and the world itself is meant to be as close to our modern day world and the songs are pretty much a standard pop affair with no real big showstoppers.

But like, even then, there still needs to be some attempt at making the music numbers via staging and blocking not be… bad. Theoretically speaking, the way you would shoot and block and film a musical scene is going to be significantly different than the way you'd just do a normal one. A musical number is a break from the reality of the world, leaving realism behind and prioritizing rhythm. So okay, let's take In the Heights, the movie, as a good recent example of this.

In the Heights isn't a perfect film. And I do have some issues with it, mainly the deviations from the original stage play and the complete gutting of Nina and Benny's storyline. But god did it feel good to watch a recent musical film that didn't absolutely hate being a musical In the Heights is admittedly a way more over show than Evan Hansen It a musical fans musical It made to have a large ensemble and have grand elaborate dance scenes and a million show-stopping numbers. So obviously the cinematography is going to reflect that in return.

Songs like 96,000 get this gorgeous pool sequence that feels straight out of classic cinema. Carnival Del Barrio gets long extended moments where the dancers simply get to play around and show off different dance styles from different countries. The opening number has a bunch of citizens in the ensemble out in the street. It can have these larger-than-life moments easier than Evan Hansen can, and it takes full advantage of that.

But that being said, there are still moments where Heights chills down and creates simpler sequences. No Me Diga is a festive and cheery number led by the closest thing the show has to comic reliefs, but something that stands out when you watch that part of the movie is just how deliberate everything on screen is. The simple act of walking across the salon and sitting on a chair manages to keep the energy of the song going with well-timed cuts that keep up the pace without being obnoxious and well-defined movements from the performers. There's not much here that's too elaborate when you get past the synced up movements of the ensembles and the mannequin heads in the back, but it still manages to feel interesting because the shots are interesting and the performers are making clear, defined, and engaging choices.

But okay, No Mediga is still a more high energy song than most of the ones in Evan Hansen. I wouldn't necessarily expect, nor would I want things like entire movable sets or weird mannequin heads anywhere in Evan Hansen. With that in mind, let's instead look at Breathe, one of the downbeat songs from In the Heights, and basically the play's first I Want song. Breathe is a slow and melancholy song about Nina, a young woman reflecting on her own anxieties and feelings of failure after struggling through her first year of college and coming back home.

To convey this on film, Nina is walking through the streets solemnly, seemingly aimlessly, observing those around her and reflecting on her own past life. Once again, we have a number without much that would be super demanding for our lead performer. The other people in the neighborhood do get more elaborate things to do, but even then the dances they do are slower, meant less for show, and more to replicate the type of dancing you might see from older couples dancing and remembering their own joy. It contrasts against Nina's feeling of aimlessness and her sadness.

The end result is that despite this number being so downbeat and depressing, you're able to understand how Nina feels directionless while still getting something that works as a scene and maintains an energy and structure to it that benefits the music. Now let's compare this to how they shot Dear Evan Hansen's I Want song, waving through a window, because good fucking lord, where to begin? So the song opens the movie and lets you graciously know right away that you're in for a nightmare because this number basically does every sort of film musical sing you could possibly do. You see, the first few minutes are honestly shot… fine.

Like, it's Evan singing to himself in a room. It's hard to fuck that up. But then the editing goes into overdrive. There's so many cuts here that are super frantic and fast, including one on every time Evan says tap.
I understand what they're doing here. They're trying to use editing to emulate what his anxiety feels like. But they did way too much. Like, you can't breathe.

It's like you don't even want to be around watching the movie anymore. I understand what they're going for, but it doesn't work, it's more funny than anything. We also get the next musical movie sin, which is overly literal interpretations of the lyrics. I get why this happens.

Once again, you have that problem where on stage you're allowed to have the actors just stand around and sing to the audience without worrying much about stage business, or props, or anything complex like that. And so it's easy to go through the lyrics and just match them up to what's going on. And in a lot of respects, it makes sense. Like, if Taylor Swift is singing about dancing in the kitchen around a refrigerator light, then yeah, you show her dancing in the kitchen around the refrigerator light.

But goddamn sometimes it can be really funny. One example of this was in the Les Mis movie in A Little Fall of Rain. The point of that number is that she's bleeding to death, She thinks it's raining because of the wet blood on her, but they just put a rain machine. Like the first time when Evan sings Waving Through a Window, he's actually looking through a window, and then when he sings Step Out of the Sun, he's actually stepping out of the car and into the sun.

And it's like, these are metaphors. You realize these are metaphors, right? There was never an actual window. It's like those TikTok videos of people doing literal interpretations of no children except this is done seriously and by a studio that spent millions of dollars on it.

You are coming down with me, hand in unlovable hands. Once Evan actually gets to the school, you run into the problem with how the extras are directed. Once again, much like the editing, I get what they're trying to do here. You see everyone else in school walking around Evan at their own pace, completely ignoring him and focusing solely on their own lives.

It's supposed to emphasize Evan's isolation and anxiety when it comes to being around others. But it's also done so fucking poorly because the extras are just wandering around with no real sense of rhythm, purpose, drive, anything. They don't need to be doing a dance number or anything, but right now it feels like they just gave them no direction but walk and then rolled the camera. It just completely zaps the energy out of what should be the climax of the song.

And it's not helped by the aforementioned weird cutting which takes things either too on beat or weirdly off beat or just does the weird moment where the camera does a 360 arc shot around Evan, but it keeps cutting and restarting where the previous cut started at. Once again, I do get that this is to emulate his anxiety. But it's doing so very poorly. When this is how you start your film out, I don't have any frame of reference as to what the film is going to look like when not in anxiety mode.

It just looks bad. Also, what the fuck is with this guy not actually hitting his drumset Backtracking a bit there a moment in this number where Evan Evan is in the car as his mom drives him to school This moment is small but incredibly incredibly awkward We have Evan singing his bit of the song while his mom is just there with him existing in the same space but failing to acknowledge what he's doing or participating in it. It just gives him a playful and comforting rub on the shoulder, which weirdly makes it worse than if she didn't acknowledge him at all- at least then it could be seen as Evan existing in his own world, divorced from everyone else. way that it's done makes it super uncomfortable. This is an issue basically all the musical numbers in the film have.

Once again, we're back in that last 5 years problem. The more grounded and realistic you make your film adaptation, the more additional players you add to a scene, the weirder it's going to be to try and force your characters to interact in it. Dear Evan Hansen doesn't have as many solos as the last 5 years does, but it still manages to look just as awkward as that movie does with basically all of its musical numbers. It certainly doesn't help that the first song we get after Waving Through a Window is For Forever, another Evan solo song which has him passionately lying as he fondly talks about his friendship with Connor to Connor's family.

Because this is a scene where only Evan sings, it's Ben Platt basically going off on a song where the people around him just have to stare and look and smile, with maybe Amy really needs a new Agent Adams interjecting with dialogue here and there. And this is a five minute song, so you have to live in this space, wanting to crawl under your chair from sheer discomfort for five whole minutes. The stage show is also like this. It's also Evan singing to a mostly silent table at the Murphy House.

The difference is that the stage show doesn't make me feel like I'm actually in someone's dining room watching a kid sing out of nowhere. The overall direction of the movie is way too grounded, way too serious, way too realistic that whenever a sparse song does happen, it feels like a surprise and actually ruins the flow of the movie and just feels very uncomfortable. Then there's just some weirdly baffling choices. Take the awkward semi-love song If I Could Tell Her, which is about Evan telling Zoe what he likes about her by pretending it was what Connor actually thought of her.

It's a very strange song since it is written like a love song and it is supposed to be the first song to start their romance plot, but it is also being presented to Zoe as if it's her brother's thoughts about her. I wouldn't know exactly how to stage this either, but I definitely wouldn't do it the way the movie does it. In the stage show, they do it in a relatively simple and basic way. Evan is in Zoe's room, which in this case is basically just a bed and a shelf, and the two get talking, and Evan gets closer and closer to Zoe until he's sitting on her bed, and it ends with him stealing a kiss.

It's simple, but it gets the job done. You see these two get more intimate as the song goes on, not just emotional but literally closer in space until the final moments, and with this you see a gradual increase in Evan's confidence. But then the movie decides to put this in the Murphy's kitchen, with the majority of the action being Evan and Zoe across from each other as they circle around the island kitchen. And like, this is a very wild disregard for cinematic conventions, because any time you've seen a guy and a girl circle around a kitchen island in film, it's in a scene where he wants to murder her and she's trying to figure out a way out.

It makes a song that was mildly creepy evolve into something intensely creepy. And it's not helped by it also cutting to these flashbacks that show the old pasty Ben Platt watching Zoey from afar across the years while singing about how much he loves her, which just really, really increases the stalker vibes. Both the distance and the flashbacks ruin the sense of intimacy these two are supposed to have, as they spend most of the song really far away from each other. It cuts to flashback, and then they're both sitting on the couch right next to each other.

The moments where the two sit beside one another lost and obscured through the edit. It just really, really isn't good. There's also just some minorly buckwild things. Like for some reason having Zoey and Requiem speed up a car and then come to a super abrupt stop, which was just not needed at all.

Super, super overkill for what's supposed to be an emotional song. That moment in You Will Be Found where they realized they need to explain why Evan's speech was filmed, so they have him mess up and kids laugh at him and take out their phones to record his embarrassment. Which is just… wild to me. Like, imagine if his speech did end up sucking and he wasn't able to turn it around.

What would they do with that upload? Post it to r slash cringe with the title, teenager drops his cue cards at suicide memorial for his best friend. Thankfully Evan didn't mess up his speech, so they instead uploaded it with the title, His Best Friend Died. You won't believe what he did next, which is the real title that they put in the actual movie for the really sad emotional scene, I shit you not.

Fucking choices. When this movie isn't making the worst choices possible, it's making the most boring ones. This film has a tendency to really, really go all in on shot-reverse shots, both in its musical numbers and also just in general. There are so many scenes that are just these long, static medium shots of the actors swapping back and forth with no other interesting camera choices or stage movements or anything.

This can be seen in scenes like the new song The Anonymous Ones, but can especially be felt in the way they shot Only Us. For context, this is the song where Zoe and Evan get together, with Zoe expressing her love for Evan and her desire to progress the relationship beyond bonding over her dead brother. It's the closest thing Dear Evan Hansen has to a romantic song, once you ignore or all the, you know, other stuff that might make it weird. And the movie decides to showcase these two growing closer by mainly showing them separated in their own frames, away from each other and across the room.

I'm not sure exactly why the film does this so often. If I had to guess, it could be because they just struggled to figure out exactly how to choreograph and frame a lot of these numbers and just defaulting to the most basic option. But another potential possibility is that it is this way because of covid restrictions, because yes, they did film this movie during the height of the pandemic, which means every shot you see on screen is a very good shot is putting someone's life at risk. So that's something, and would explain why they really try to keep everyone six feet apart and in their own frames.

There are some good moments that I will give credit for. Sincerely me, while still overall not great, especially toward the end with the random fucking go-karts and shit, manages to be the best number in the film by actually doing dancing, starting off with a fun single take shot and just generally feeling more structured and elaborate than the rest of the numbers. It really feels like they put a lot more focus here than they did with the others. There's also some bit of cinematography I like.

I know I ragged on For Forever, but I do think it's neat how the song basically ends by framing Evan on his own by the window, Connor's parents on their own, and then Zoe getting the frame to herself as they look at Evan. It shows the divide. How the parents are fully buying into Evan while Zoe is reluctant and distant from the others. But what makes me really like it is toward the end, during Words Fail, when we find ourselves back in the dining room with Evan once again toward the window, but this time with Zoe and her parents across from him sharing the frame, showing how united they are in this moment in their disgust toward this fucking kid.

It's like the one standout time of the cinematography actually doing a good job expressing how the characters feel through framing. As a whole, Dear Evan Hansen's directing is just… not good. It fails to understand how to best elevate the material, how to translate the work to stage, and how to make the most out of the musical numbers. I mean, beyond just looking at individual scenes, the film itself has an overall problem with its tone and direction that bring it down hard.

Part of the problem with doing the thing where you get these award-aspiring directors to make a film aimed primarily to garner critical acclaim and award recognition, and in my opinion Dear Evan Hansen is 100% an award bait movie, is that they're going to do what they can to emphasize the aspects of the project they feel will get it nominated for an award. As said before, this usually means trying their best to ground it to a sense of realism, one that's not necessarily gritty, but is raw. And not only does Dear Evan Hansen do this, but it also comes with the extra benefit of just sapping basically every ounce of comedy out of the scene and really playing up the emotions of everyone at all times. Basically every scene, every performance is shot and performed like they want you to cry.

That you're supposed to be moved by how profound it is. I was honestly shocked that they didn't just slap a for your consideration banner on the entire movie. The weird thing about this is that the stage show is a dark comedy. Like, it doesn't go all in on the dark comedy angle the same way similar works like, say, World's Greatest Dad do, but it was still funny when it needed to be. made sure to have a punchline, to have comedic beats, to have moments that broke up the tension.

I mean, the reason why Sincerely Me is basically the fan favourite number is because it goes all in on the dark comedy aspect in a way the rest of the songs don't. And despite the movie maintaining this song, it basically drops every other instance of humour. It's like the filmmakers saw the way certain parts of the fandom viewed Dear Evan Hansen as this sincere, heartfelt, tearjerker play about mental health, and decided to go all in on it. I mean, look at the way the marketing focused so heavily on You Will Be Found, the song that's supposed to be a double entendre about how Evan is going to inevitably be revealed as a liar, he'll be found, and used it completely sincerely as a song about mental health.

And every single interview and piece of promotional material is about the emotional impact of the story and how important and meaningful it all is, and it's so not the right way to go about this. I'm not just saying this because I think that movies should have more quips or something, I'm not Joss Whedon, I'm fine with a serious, introspective film that tries to do something emotional. And I can understand why, from their perspective, they might have thought that removing the comedy would show more respect for the subject matter and come off as less tasteless. but weirdly enough, it comes off as more so? When you have those darkly comedic elements, you're allowed to get away with things you probably wouldn't have otherwise.

Dear Evan Hansen is a show with a deeply intense subject matter and a very complicated main character. The presence of jokes and humor in the stage show act as a sort of acknowledgement of that fact. It's the show giving a wink toward the audience, letting us know that it understands the absurdity and potential tastelessness of what the characters are doing. And more importantly, it makes Evan more charming and relatable and human.

By showing him engaging in conversations with others, allowing himself to be funny and tell jokes and have moments that are played for soft laughs, we can gain more sympathy for him throughout the show and see him more as a flawed human being. In the movie though, where everything is played so dry and seriously, you have no choice but to examine the implications of everything going on. Without Evan's awkward banter with Zoe played for laughs, the film forces you to think about how creepy their relationship actually is. With the school's sad reaction to Connor's death played almost completely seriously, you have no choice but to think about how little the play is actually about him and how fucked up it is to use a teenager's suicide purely as a plot device without actually fundamentally exploring the implication.

And without the charm Ben Platt could give Evan on stage, your mind is eventually going to drift off into examining how the film actually does explore his mental health issues and mental health in general and whether or not it actually covers the subject well I think this is a big reason why critical reaction to the movie has been significantly worse than that of the musical Beyond Ben Platt age beyond the musical numbers not being very good or well-directed, the drastic tonal shift honestly makes the material so much worse. By trying to make the work deeper, they essentially forced critics to dig into it more, which meant the work being basically exposed and torn apart in ways it really hadn't before. Musical movies are very hard to do. summary: The speaker discusses the musical Dear Evan Hansen and its recent film adaptation. They analyze what went wrong with the movie and how it failed to translate the stage show to the screen. The speaker also touches on the trend of musical adaptations and the challenges of bringing Broadway shows to the big screen. The film adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen has several issues, including poor casting choices, particularly with Ben Platt playing Evan Hansen at an age that doesn't align with the character's high school age.

The film also struggles with translating the stage production to screen, making it hard to empathize with Evan's character. The music in the film is also criticized, with added songs feeling shoehorned and generic. The adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen for film has several issues, primarily with the cutting of certain songs and changes to the script. The speaker argues that these changes, such as cutting the song 'Does Anybody Have a Map?'

and replacing 'Good For You' with a two-minute argument scene, detract from the story and characters. The film's attempts to address criticisms of the stage show, like making Evan admit to lying on social media, fall flat. The speaker also criticizes the film's direction and cinematography, saying they don't effectively translate the stage show to screen. The speaker discusses the difficulties of adapting stage musicals to film, using Dear Evan Hansen and The Last Five Years as examples.

They highlight the differences between the two mediums, particularly in terms of how time and space are conveyed, and how musical numbers are staged and shot. The speaker argues that the film adaptations of these musicals often struggle to translate the unique qualities of the stage productions to the screen. The film adaptation of Dear Evan Hansen has been criticized for its awkward and uncomfortable musical numbers, poor directing, and drastic tonal shift from the stage show. The movie's attempts to ground the story in realism come across as forced and unnatural, leading to a dull and depressing viewing experience.

The speaker argues that the film's problems are not unique to Dear Evan Hansen, but rather a symptom of a larger issue with musical film adaptations. The speaker discusses their love for musicals, specifically highlighting Stephen Sondheim's works, and analyzes the current state of movie musicals, citing the box office failures of Cats, Dear Evan Hansen, and In the Heights. They express concern that film adaptations often lack the essence of what makes musicals great, such as strong choreography and emotionally explosive numbers. The speaker also promotes their content on Nebula and CuriosityStream.

do to a person, and they just don't. And finally, there's the fact that, for all

possible and yet is equally alone and desperate for friendship and recognition. And depending

00:27:13.746 --> 00:27:19.106
